{{about|Robert Clyde Packer (1935–2001) known as '''Clyde Packer'''|grandfather Robert Clyde Packer (1879–1934) also known as '''Clyde Packer'''|Robert Clyde Packer}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox politician | honorific_prefix = [[The Honourable]] | name = Clyde Packer | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | office = Member of the [[New South Wales Legislative Council]] | term_start = 23 April 1964 | term_end = 22 April 1976 | predecessor = [[Henry Thompson (Australian politician)|Henry Thompson]] | successor = [[Bill Sandwith]] | birth_name = Robert Clyde Packer | birth_date = {{Birth date|1935|7|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], Australia | death_date = {{Death date and age|2001|4|8|1935|7|22|df=y}} | death_place = [[Santa Barbara, California]], United States | alma_mater = [[Geelong Grammar School]] | occupation = *[[Media proprietor]] *Chairman, [[Australian Consolidated Press]] (formerly) *Chairman, [[Nine Network]] (formerly) | years_active = 1956-1987 | profession = [[Politics|Politician]] | employer = | organization = | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth $AUD 357 Million = | height = {{convert|6|ft|3|in|m}} | weight = {{convert|240|lb|kg}} | television = | title = | party = [[Liberal Party of Australia (New South Wales Division)|Liberal Party]] | movement = | opponents = | boards = [[Australian Consolidated Press]], [[Nine Network]] | religion = | denomination = | spouse = {{marriage|Angela Money|1961|1972}}
{{marriage|Kate Clifford|1977|2001}} | children = Francis Clyde Packer | father = [[Frank Packer]] | mother = Gretel Bullmore | relations = {{unbulleted list|{{nowrap|[[Robert Clyde Packer|R. C. Packer]] (paternal grandfather)}}|{{nowrap|[[Herbert Bullmore]] (maternal grandfather)}}|[[Kerry Packer]] (brother)|[[James Packer]] (nephew)}} | known_for = [[Packer family]] | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = }} '''Robert Clyde Packer''' (22 July 1935{{spaced ndash}}8 April 2001), usually known as '''Clyde Packer''', was the son of Australian newspaper magnate [[Frank Packer]] and the elder brother of media baron [[Kerry Packer]]. From 23 April 1964 to 22 April 1976 he was a Member of the [[New South Wales Legislative Council]] for the [[Liberal Party of Australia (New South Wales Division)|Liberal Party]]. Packer was originally intended to be his father's heir before a falling-out in 1972 resulted in Kerry inheriting the family business in 1974 upon Frank's death. Among his many business activities, Packer founded the independent [[Spin Records (Australian Label)|Spin Records]] label, which released many successful singles and albums from 1966 to 1972, including [[Bee Gees|The Bee Gees]]' "[[Spicks and Specks (song)|Spicks and Specks]]" (1966) and the original Australian cast recording of the rock musical ''[[Hair (musical)#Early international productions|Hair]]'' (1969). In 1976 Packer relocated to the United States, initially living in Los Angeles before moving to Santa Barbara. Robert Clyde Packer died of heart and lung failure on 8 April 2001, aged 65. ==Early life== Clyde Packer was born Robert Clyde Packer on 22 July 1935.{{cite news | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100221213304/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/clyde-packer-729012.html | url = http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article35180.ece | title = Clyde Packer – Obituary | last = Milliken | first = Robert | work = [[The Independent]] | archivedate = 21 February 2010 | date = 12 April 2001 | accessdate = 14 October 2013 }} He was named for his paternal grandfather, [[Robert Clyde Packer]] (1879–1934), who had established the Packer media dynasty. Clyde's father was [[Frank Packer|Sir Frank Packer]] (1906–1974), a media proprietor who controlled [[Australian Consolidated Press]] and the [[Nine Network]]. His mother, Gretel Joyce née Bullmore (1907–1960), was the daughter of [[Herbert Bullmore]] (1874–1937), an Australian-born physician and rugby union player who represented [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]].{{cite web| title = Players & Officials/Herbert Bullmore | url = http://www.espnscrum.com/scrum/rugby/player/1513.html | work = ESPNScrum | publisher = [[ESPN]] | accessdate = 17 October 2013 }} His younger brother was [[Kerry Packer]] (17 December 1937{{spaced ndash}}26 December 2005).{{cite news | work = [[The Age]] | date = 28 December 2005 | page = 7 | title = Kerry Francis Bullmore Packer 1937–2005 | url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2005/12/27/1135445572500.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 | accessdate = 17 October 2013 }} During their early childhood Clyde and Kerry were cared for by a nurse, Inez McCracken, whom Clyde described as a "surrogate mother" who made "an unbearable childhood tolerable".{{cite news | url = http://www.news.com.au/opinion/indigo-is-the-luckiest-packer-of-them-all/story-e6frfs99-1111117043148 | title = Indigo Is the Luckiest Packer of Them All | last = Connolly | first = Fiona | work = [[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Telegraph]] | publisher = [[News Corp Australia]] | date = 29 July 2008 | accessdate = 17 October 2013 }} Packer was a boarder at [[Cranbrook School, Sydney|Cranbrook School]] in Sydney and then [[Geelong Grammar School|Geelong Grammar]] in Victoria. He took part in various sports at school, including boxing, cricket, and rugby. == Media career== In the early 1950s, instead of attending university as he wished, Clyde Packer heeded his father's directive "You go to work for me ... You'll learn far more in the school of hard knocks". He joined Australian Consolidated Press (ACP) as a journalist and sub-editor of its flagship, ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]''. For six months he worked at the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' in London. In 1954 ACP launched a magazine, ''Weekend'', with [[Donald Horne]] as editor and Packer on staff.{{cite web | url = http://ketupa.net/packer2.htm | title = Packer: Landmarks | publisher = Ketupa.net | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130403065954/http://ketupa.net/packer2.htm | archivedate = 3 April 2013 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=v157FNdS-OcC&pg=PA23&lpg=PA23&dq=clyde+packer+peter+coleman&source=bl&ots=d4hoRm6Z_X&sig=ndUGXgLHfrk7QMDdIfuVw3cG7AQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pDVcUpj1IcSfiQfzjoCICA&redir_esc=y#v=snippet&q=clyde%20packer&f=false | title = On How I Came to Write The Lucky Country | last = Horne | first = Donald | authorlink = Donald Horne | publisher = [[University of Melbourne|Melbourne University Press]] (MUP) | location = Melbourne | year = 2006 | pages = 12–18, 23, 75–76, 81 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | isbn = 978-0-52285-222-6 | series = Issue 4 of MUP Masterworks }} By 1956 Packer was a director at ACP, Frank purchased the rights to Sydney TV station [[TCN|TCN-9]] – the first Australian station to begin regular broadcasting. By 1957 ''Weekend'' employed [[Lillian Roxon]] as a journalist and later a sub-editor. When Queensland authorities wanted to ban the magazine Packer and Horne successfully fought the injunction in court. ACP followed, in February 1958, with the launch of ''The Observer'', an "intellectual magazine" where Horne was editor and Packer was his boss. Packer allowed Horne to hire various contributors including [[Bruce Beresford]], [[Peter Coleman]], [[Robert Hughes (critic)|Robert Hughes]], [[Barry Humphries]], and [[James McAuley]]. Packer was later the talent manager for Humphries.{{cite web | url = http://from.ph/417219 | title = 97/272/1-2/14 Photographic print, black and white, 'Taking a leak', Clyde Packer and Barry Humphreys at urinals in Luna Park, by Janice Wakely, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1976 | last1 = Powerhouse Museum | authorlink1 = Powerhouse Museum | last2 = Wakely | first2 = Janice | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | publisher = Powerhouse Museum, Australia }} In 1958 Packer had hired [[Francis James]] of Anglican Press to print ''The Observer'' but after three years and a run of "broken deadlines, overcharges, misprints, [and] slow deliveries" Horne and Packer had taken that job away. In 1960 ACP were involved in a commercial rivalry with [[Rupert Murdoch]]'s [[News Corp Australia|News Limited]], over interests in print media in Sydney.{{cite web | url = http://inside.org.au/nine-tenths-of-the-law/ | title = Nine-tenths of the Law | last = Tiffen | first = Rodney | authorlink = Rodney Tiffen | publisher = Inside Story | date = 3 June 2010 | accessdate = 14 October 2013 | issn = 1837-0497 }} ACP had made an offer to buy Anglican Press when it was placed in receivership so that they could publish suburban newspapers in opposition to Murdoch's recent acquisitions. In June 1960 the rivalry between the two groups turned into a physical brawl where men hired by Murdoch fought with Packer, Kerry and their associates over the control of Anglican Press building. The Murdoch group had a photographer take evidence of the fracas and their afternoon newspaper, ''[[The Daily Mirror (Australia)|The Daily Mirror]]'', ran a front page article headlined "Knight's Sons in City Brawl" with a photo of Packer ejecting the manager of Anglican Press, John Willis, into the street.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?ei=5dddUt3yNsP_iAfl7oHIAw&id=IePgAAAAMAAJ&dq=clyde+packer&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22Clyde+Packer%22 | title = The Rise and Rise of Kerry Packer Uncut | last = Barry | first = Paul | authorlink = Paul Barry | publisher = Bantam Books / ABC Books ([[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]) | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-1-86325-331-4 | page = 128 | accessdate = 16 October 2013 }} Also that year Frank bought majority interests in Melbourne TV station [[GTV (Australia)|GTV-9]] which was combined with TCN-9 to form Australia's first national network, [[Nine Network]]. In 1961 Packer was promoted to assistant general manager of ACP. During that year two ACP publications ''Weekend'' and ''The [[Australian Woman's Mirror]]'' were merged to form ''[[Everybody's (Australian magazine)|Everybody's]]'' with Horne editing and Packer as its manager. In 1965 Packer was made general manager of ACP and founded a record label also called Everybody's as a joint venture with [[Harry M. Miller]] (New Zealand-born promoter) and Nat Kipner (record producer and former co-owner of [[Sunshine Records (Australia)|Sunshine Records]]).{{cite web | url = http://www.milesago.com/Industry/everybodys.htm | title = Record Labels – Everybody's | last1 = Kimball | first1 = Duncan | publisher = Milesago: Australasian Music and Popular Culture 1964–1975. Ice Productions | year = 2002 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 }} However Sydney radio stations were reluctant to play singles issued by that label due to the promotion of ACP's magazine. In January the following year the label was re-launched as [[Spin Records (Australian Label)|Spin Records]] with Kipner as house producer.{{cite web | archiveurl = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/35967/20030624-0000/www.milesago.com/industry/spin.htm | url = http://www.milesago.com/industry/spin.htm | title = Record Labels – Spin Records | last1 = Kimball | first1 = Duncan | publisher = Milesago: Australasian Music and Popular Culture 1964–1975. Ice Productions | archivedate = 24 June 2003 | year = 2002 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 }} During that year Spin Records signed [[Bee Gees|The Bee Gees]] and issued their hit single, "[[Spicks and Specks (song)|Spicks and Specks]]", which reached No. 4 on the ''[[Go-Set]]'' National Top 40.{{cite web | url = http://www.poparchives.com.au/gosetcharts/1966/19661109.html | last1 = Nimmervoll | first1 = Ed | authorlink1 = Ed Nimmervoll | work = [[Go-Set]] | title = National Top 40 | publisher = Waverley Press | date = 9 November 1966 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 }}{{Cite book | last1 = McFarlane | first1 = Ian | authorlink1 = Ian McFarlane | title = [[Encyclopedia of Australian Rock and Pop]] | chapter = Encyclopedia entry for 'The Bee Gees' | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040807050507/http://www.whammo.com.au/encyclopedia.asp?articleid=87 | chapter-url = http://www.whammo.com.au/encyclopedia.asp?articleid=87 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | year = 1999 | publisher = [[Allen & Unwin]] | location = [[St Leonards, New South Wales|St Leonards, NSW]] | archivedate = 7 August 2004 | isbn = 1-86508-072-1 }} During the late-1960s Packer took on more of the administration of Network Nine while Spin Records continued to release singles and albums by various Australian artists. In June 1969 Miller produced the Australian stage version of ''[[Hair (musical)#Early international productions|Hair]]'', a rock musical.{{cite news | url = http://www.orlok.com/hair/holding/articles/HairArticles/NYT6-7-69.html | title = ''Hair'' Reaches Australia | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = 7 June 1969 | page = 26 | publisher = ''Hair'' Online Archives | accessdate = 15 October 2013 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.milesago.com/Stage/hair.htm | title = Stage Shows – ''Hair'': Original Australian Production, 1969–71 | last1 = Kimball | first1 = Duncan | publisher = Milesago: Australasian Music and Popular Culture 1964–1975. Ice Productions | year = 2002 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 }} Spin Records issued the soundtrack, ''Hair – Australian Cast Soundtrack'', by the end of the year, which was banned in Queensland and New Zealand. === Dispute with father === In 1970 Clyde Packer became joint managing director of Nine Network with his father, Frank. Clyde later recalled: "[I]t was a very equitable arrangement ... I had the responsibility and he had the authority". Late in the next year Clyde Packer launched ''[[A Current Affair (Australian TV series)|A Current Affair]]'' on the Nine network, with [[Mike Willesee]] hosting.{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/stories/s275373.htm | title = Clyde Packer dies at 65 | last = Carmody | first = Rebecca | work = The World Today | publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] | date = 10 April 2001 | accessdate = 17 October 2013 }} In 1972, Willesee organised for ''A Current Affair'' to have an on-air interview with then-union leader, [[Bob Hawke]], during an industrial dispute. When Frank heard of the arrangement he vetoed the decision to allow Hawke on his network, undermining Clyde's authority. Willesee later declared: "You can't run a current affairs program, as you couldn't run a serious newspaper, and have people tell you you can't have the leader of the Trade Union movement". Packer resigned his posts at the Nine Network and ACP, and later reflected on the split: "I suspect my father was as glad to get rid of me as I was to get rid of him". Their public falling-out followed years of tight control by Frank. According to [[Paul Barry]], "Clyde Packer ... was also frequently dressed down and abused in public by his father, Sir Frank. Into his late thirties, Clyde was still treated like a stupid, disobedient little boy, until he could take no more and rebelled against such tyranny, splitting clearly and completely with his father".{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=V-KjZ8p3N2oC&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32&dq=%22clyde+packer%22+dressed+down&source=bl&ots=I5OHw0uQB7&sig=JAa4RE0teFCE6Vo9sG1YD5mJcxY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=GeJdUs_fDofliAfR5oDwBg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22clyde%20packer%22&f=false | last1 = Donaldson | first1 = Mike | last2 = Poynting | first2 = Scott | title = Ruling Class Men: Money, Sex, Power | page = 32 | publisher = Peter Lang | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-3-03911-137-4 | accessdate = 16 October 2013 }} On his father's death in May 1974, the family estate, valued at A$100 million passed directly to Kerry.{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ssSijGtEWyAC&pg=PA183#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Giants of Tourism |first1=James E.S. |last1 =Highham |first2=Scott |last2 = Cohen|page=182|publisher=CABI |year= 2010 |accessdate=18 July 2013}} In 1976, Clyde sold his quarter-share of the family business for A$4 million to Kerry, who went on to become Australia's richest man. == Political career == Clyde Packer had joined the [[Liberal Party of Australia (New South Wales Division)|Liberal Party]] in 1954.{{cite web | url = http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/Prod/parlment/members.nsf/ec78138918334ce3ca256ea200077f5d/9498f80873fd362dca256e8a0023b056?OpenDocument | title = The Hon. Robert Clyde Packer | publisher = [[Parliament of New South Wales]] | accessdate = 14 October 2013 }} He became Vice-President of the Paddington-Waverley branch and a member of the Bligh state electorate conference. On 21 November 1963 he was elected as a Member of the [[New South Wales Legislative Council]], with his appointment starting on 23 April 1964 and ending on 22 April 1976. Frank had a meeting with then-Prime Minister, [[Robert Menzies]], they discussed a possible diplomatic appointment for Frank which Menzies declined.{{cite web | url = http://www.nla.gov.au/bridget-griffen-foley/press-proprietors-and-political-pundits-the-media-and-politics-in-postwar-australia | title = Press Proprietors and Political Pundits: The Media and Politics in Postwar Australia | last = Griffen-Foley | first = Bridget | publisher = [[National Library of Australia]] | date = 6 December 2003| accessdate = 18 October 2013}} Menzies helped Packer draft his maiden speech to the parliament. Packer was the Honorary Treasurer of the Children's Surgical Research Fund, a member of New South Wales Society for Crippled Children and New South Wales Committee Council for Civil Liberties. Although a conservative politician, Packer supported freedom of speech, he voted against a bill to ban pornography.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=TNLpoUK-eUkC&pg=PA91&lpg=PA91&dq=%22clyde+packer%22+politician&source=bl&ots=u6jzUrPt_M&sig=QQ6-OCP8bcpWtCv8cAhufYcKuDM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lH9fUtLLOu-ZiQeRhYGoCQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=clyde&f=false | title = Mother of Rock: The Lillian Roxon Story | last = Milliken | first = Robert | publisher = Black Inc | pages = 89–92, 181 | year = 2010 | isbn = 978-1-92186-656-2 }} During early 1974 he worked with New South Wales Premier, [[Robert Askin]], to develop a series of ads run by [[John Singleton (Australian entrepreneur)|John Singleton]]'s agency against the incumbent Prime Minister, [[Gough Whitlam]], and his [[Australian Labor Party]] in the lead up to the [[Australian federal election, 1974|federal election]] in May.{{cite book | chapterurl = https://books.google.com/books?id=RnG_tEGjSloC&pg=PA37&dq=%22clyde+packer%22+voting&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zedgUqKWAsGgkAXZ9oGYCA&ved=0CEMQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22clyde%20packer%22%20voting&f=false | title = Australian Dictionary of Biography, 1981–1990 | editor1-last = Langmore | editor1-first = Diane | editor2-last = Bennet | editor2-first = Darryl | chapter = Askin, Sir Robert (Robin) William | accessdate = 18 October 2013 | publisher = The Miegunyah Press | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-0-52285-382-7 }} == Counter-cultural involvement == After Clyde Packer's resignation from the family's media interests in 1972, he became briefly involved in the [[counter-culture]] – famously donning a [[kaftan]], claiming that it was "better than dieting". In the next year Packer established an adult sex magazine, ''Forum'', with [[Bettina Arndt]] as consulting editor, and later editor and then publisher.{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/talkingheads/txt/s1951266.htm | title = Transcripts: Bettina Arndt | last = Thompson | first = Peter | authorlink = | work = [[Talking Heads (Australian TV series)|Talking Heads]] | publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) | date = 18 June 2007 | accessdate = 17 October 2013 }} In March that year he explained his motivation for launching the new magazine in the context of changes in the role of sexuality.{{cite web | url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/39361891?q=Packer%2C+Clyde+Forum&c=article&sort=holdings+desc&_=1381927491049&versionId=188158366 | title = Why I Publish ''Forum'' | last = Packer | first = Clyde | work = [[Quadrant (magazine)|Quadrant]] | volume = 17 | issue = 2 | date = March–April 1973 | publisher = [[National Library of Australia]] | pages = 65–69 | issn = 0033-5002 }} Note: only an Abstract is available online. He moved to California in 1976 and thereafter rarely returned to Australia. In America, he pursued interests in film, surf culture, and magazine publishing. He bought ''[[Surfing Magazine]]'' in 1976 and during the mid-1980s he expanded his interests establishing the sister magazines, ''Bodyboarding Magazine'' and ''Volleyball''.{{cite web | url = http://www.surfline.com/surfing-a-to-z/surfing-magazine-history_920/ | title = ''Surfing Magazine'' History | last = Borte | first = Jason | publisher = Surfline | accessdate = 18 October 2013 }} In 1984 Packer released a book, ''No Return Ticket'', where he interviewed nine fellow Australian expatriates: [[Robert Hughes (critic)|Robert Hughes]], [[Gordon Chater]], Graham Fraser, [[Judith Anderson|Dame Judith Anderson]], [[James Wolfensohn]], [[Germaine Greer]], [[Maxwell Newton]], [[Zoe Caldwell]], and [[Sumner Locke Elliott]].{{Citation | last1 = Packer | first1 = Clyde | title = No Return Ticket | publication-date = 1984 | publisher = [[Angus & Robertson]] | isbn = 978-0-207-15028-9 }} According to ''[[The Canberra Times]]''{{'}} Mark Thomas the book is a "quirky, frothy anachronism" where the interviewees "whinge about the Australian cultural cringe in terms which no young Australian would find comprehensible".{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article122533267 | title = Tickets on Themselves |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] | date = 8 December 1984 | accessdate = 17 October 2013 | page = 25 | publisher=National Library of Australia}} Also during 1984 the [[Costigan Commission]] issued a draft report into its investigation into the [[Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union|Painters and Dockers Union]] which implicated a prominent businessman codenamed "Goanna" in [[tax evasion]] and [[organised crime]] activities.{{cite news | url = http://resources.news.com.au/files/2012/08/24/1226457/727948-aus-news-file-kerry-packer.pdf | title = Packermain | publisher = news.com.au | format = [[PDF]] | date = 24 August 2012 | accessdate = 17 October 2013 }} In September that year news reports published leaked case summaries and Kerry outed himself as "Goanna" but denied all allegations. When Packer was contacted he observed that his brother "had his rights trampled on and his name defamed". The Costigan Commission had also contacted the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] and [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]] to investigate Packer's own activities after a US surfing official claimed that one of Packer's local magazines was a front for drug-trafficking. Packer was never officially accused of any wrongdoing related to these investigations. In January 1987 Packer told Ali Cromie from ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' that he had left Australia because he "would have a better future in America than Australia".{{cite news | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19870123&id=FfVjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=veQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3165,4932217 | title = The Other Packer: a View from Afar | last = Cromie | first = Ali | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 23 January 1987 | accessdate = 17 October 2013 }} Initially Packer had made documentaries but most of his subsequent work was in publishing. He also ran a consultancy business, Magazine Investment and Management. Cromie described his relationship with Kerry "they got on well without being especially close. He disputes reports that portray their relationship in any other way. 'I had animosity with my father – never with my brother'". == Personal life == On 25 May 1961 Clyde Packer married Angela May Money (born 9 March 1938).{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27979257 |title=Social and Personal: Daughter Born Yesterday | newspaper = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 10 March 1938 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | page = 23 | publisher = [[National Library of Australia]] }} Angela was the elder daughter of Dr. Rex Money, a [[Macquarie Street, Sydney|Macquarie Street]] specialist and neurosurgeon, and Dorothy "Noppy" née Wilkinson.{{cite web | url = http://www.thehills.nsw.gov.au/external/hillsvoices/roussel.htm | title = Aberdoon House 2 | last = Heimans | first = Frank | others = transcribed by Glenys Murray | publisher = [[The Hills Shire|Baulkham Hills Shire Council]] | date = June 2007 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131024082255/http://www.thehills.nsw.gov.au/external/hillsvoices/roussel.htm | archivedate = 24 October 2013 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite news | url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article46940022 | title = Social – Roundabout | last = Coles | first = Mary | newspaper = [[The Australian Women's Weekly]] | date = 7 June 1961 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | page = 16 | publisher = [[National Library of Australia]] }}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17467063 |title=Baby's Christening on Sunday | newspaper = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 20 May 1938 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | page = 4 | publisher = National Library of Australia }} The couple were married at [[Woollahra#Churches|All Saints Church, Woollahra]] with Kerry as best man and David Halliday as groomsman. Clyde and Angela had a son, Francis Clyde Packer.{{cite news | url = http://www.pew.com.au/pew-articles/2001/5/16/sydneys-last-goodbye-for-the-packer-who-ran-away/ | title = Sydney's Last Goodbye for the Packer Who Ran Away | last = Lawson | first = Valerie | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 16 May 2001 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20131015080341/http://www.pew.com.au/pew-articles/2001/5/16/sydneys-last-goodbye-for-the-packer-who-ran-away/ | archivedate = 15 October 2013 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite web | url = http://reviews.media-culture.org.au/modules.php?name=News&file=print&sid=2724 | title = Rhetoric: ''Great Australian Eulogies'' | last = Yarrow | first = Megan | publisher = M/C Reviews ([[Axel Bruns (scholar)|Axel Bruns]]) | date = 5 August 2008 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20131015080347/http://reviews.media-culture.org.au/modules.php?name=News&file=print&sid=2724 | archivedate = 15 October 2013 | df = dmy-all }} In 1972 Packer and Angela divorced.{{cite news | url = http://www.santabarbara.com.au/santa-barbara-articles/2001/4/10/clyde-the-packer-who-gave-dr-death-the-boot-dies-in-california// | title = Clyde, The Packer Who Gave Dr Death the Boot, Dies in California | last = Lawson | first = Valerie | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 10 April 2001 | accessdate = 15 October 2013 }} Packer had relocated to Los Angeles by 1976 where he married his second wife, Kate Clifford, a former model from Brisbane, on 7 July 1977. By 1987 Clyde and Kate were living in the Santa Barbara suburb of Montecito. Clyde developed heart and kidney problems. He was on a dialysis machine for treatment and had a kidney donated from his architect. From 1999 he had been bedridden for two years. (Kerry also had heart and kidney problems and obtained a new kidney from his helicopter pilot.) Robert Clyde Packer died on 8 April 2001, aged 65. He died of heart and lung failure. A memorial for Packer was held in Sydney on 16 May 2001 with a eulogy "Dear Clyde" which was written by Barry Humphries and read by Packer's son, Francis. Other speakers at the memorial were [[John Laws]], [[Harry M. Miller]] and [[Peter Coleman]]. In the TV mini-series, ''[[Power Games: The Packer-Murdoch War]]'' (September 2013), Clyde Packer was portrayed by Alexander England.{{cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/box-seat/land-of-the-rising-sons-20130830-2su5z.html | title = Land of the Rising Sons | last = Hardie | first = Giles | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 2 September 2013 | accessdate = 17 October 2013 }} == Bibliography == * {{cite journal | last1 = Minogue | first1 = Dennis | last2 = Packer | first2 = Clyde | title = Packer's $15 million deal | journal = New Times | location = Sydney | publication-date = September 1977 | volume=1 | issue = Sept 1977 | pages = 4–10 | url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/39261696 | accessdate = 17 October 2013 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Packer | first1 = Clyde | title = ''Sir John Monash'' [Book Review] | journal = [[Quadrant (magazine)|Quadrant]] | location = Sydney | publication-date = April 1983 | volume = 27 | issue = 4 | pages = 88–90 | issn = 0033-5002 }} * {{Citation | last1 = Packer | first1 = Clyde | title = No Return Ticket | publication-date = 1984 | publisher = [[Angus & Robertson]] | isbn = 978-0-207-15028-9 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Packer | first1 = Clyde | title = Computers: Santa Barbara letter | journal = [[Quadrant (magazine)|Quadrant]] | location = Sydney | publication-date = July 1984 | volume=28 | issue = 7-8 | pages = 59–60 | issn = 0033-5002 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Packer | first1 = Clyde | title = An interview with Sumner Locke Elliott | journal = [[Quadrant (magazine)|Quadrant]] | location = Sydney | publication-date = November 1984 | volume = 28 | issue = 11 | pages = 19–23 | issn = 0033-5002 }} * {{cite AV media notes | title = Interview with Clyde Packer, journalist | date = October 1991 |chapter= |url= |accessdate= | first = Clyde | last = Packer | first2 = Peter | last2 = Coleman | authorlink2 = Peter Coleman |page= |pages= | type = [[compact cassette|audio cassette]] |publisher= |id= |location= |ref= | oclc = 220861187 }} == References == {{Refbegin}} ;General * {{Citation | last1 = Coleman | first1 = Peter | authorlink1 = Peter Coleman | title = Clyde Packer | journal = [[Quadrant (magazine)|Quadrant]] | publication-date = 1 July 2001 | publisher = Quadrant Magazine Company, Inc | issn = 0033-5002 }} * {{cite book | chapter = 11: Barry Humphries on Clyde Packer: 'Dear Clyde' | last = Humphries | first = Barry | authorlink = Barry Humphries | title = Great Australian Eulogies | editor = Richard Walsh | pages = 75–80 | publisher = [[Allen & Unwin]] | isbn = 978-1-74115-620-1 | year = 2008 }} ;Specific {{Refend}} {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == * [http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/PhotoSearchItemDetail.asp?M=0&B=30451958&SE=1 "Sir Frank Packer, chairman of the committee which organised the America's Cup challenge by Australia, with his two sons Clyde (left) and Kerry. Clyde is 6 feet 3 inches and 240 pounds; Kerry is 6 feet 2 inches and 215 pounds. Sir Frank is Managing Director of Consolidated Press Ltd, Sydney"] photograph of Clyde, Sir Frank and Kerry Packer, 1962. Digital copy viewed at [[National Archives of Australia]]. Item details for: A1200, L41912. * [http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=417219 "Taking a Leak"] photograph of Clyde Packer and [[Barry Humphries]] by Janice Wakely, 1976. Held by [[Powerhouse Museum]], Sydney. * [http://articles.latimes.com/2001/apr/10/local/me-49156 "R.C. Packer; Publisher in Australia, U.S."] obituary, ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 10 April 2001. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Packer, Clyde}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:2001 deaths]] [[Category:Australian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Australian people of English descent]] [[Category:People educated at Geelong Grammar School]] [[Category:Organ transplant recipients]] [[Category:People from Sydney]] [[Category:Liberal Party of Australia members of the Parliament of New South Wales]] [[Category:Packer family|Clyde]] [[Category:20th-century Australian politicians]] [[Category:20th-century Australian businesspeople]]

{{Infobox musical artist |name = DJ Candlestick |image = |background = non_performing_personnel |birth_name = Omar Barton |origin = [[Houston]], [[Texas]], [[United States]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1985|6|21}} |birth_place = [[Houston]], [[Texas]], [[United States]] |instrument = [[Turntablism|Turntables]]
[[Turntablism|Turntable]] |genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] |occupation = [[record producer]], [[DJ]], [[Executive (management)|executive]] |years_active = 2004–present |label = [[ChopNotSlop ENT.]] (2009–present) |website = [http://www.chopnotslop.com www.chopnotslop.com] }} '''Omar Barton''' (born June 21, 1985), better known by his [[stage name]] '''DJ Candlestick''', is an [[United States|American]] record producer, radio personality, and [[DJ]]. He is a member of [[The Chopstars]] of the ChopNotSlop subgenre, on-air personality for [[KQBT]] 93.7 The Beat Houston, The Choice 90.9 [[KTSU]] and DJ for The Nice Guys. He is the DJ behind [[Chop Care]] as well as many other ChopNotSlop mixtapes. ==Biography== DJ Candlestick has been DJing since 2001. He is a member of [[The Chopstars]] (ChopNotSlop subgenre). He is also a member of the Houston-based rap group The Nice Guys.{{Cite web |url=http://www.houstonpress.com/2011-03-10/music/meet-the-niceguys/ |title=Houston Press: The Nice Guys}} ==ChopNotSlop Radio== ChopNotSlop Radio is an online radio station that specializes in ChopNotSlop music. It is the first 24 hours [[chopped and screwed]] radio station. It was created in 2008 with the intentions of helping keep the subgenre that [[DJ Screw]] had created. The station currently has one live show every Wednesday that features OG RON C, DJ Candlestick, DJ Slim K, DJ Lil Steve and DJ Hollygrove with live-on-air turntablism where they chop and screw music. ==Partial discography == * 2011: ''[[Chop Care]]: [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]] OG Ron C Edition'' * 2015: [[Little Dragon]] Nabuma Purple Rubberband {{cite web |url=http://www.adultswim.com/music/little-dragon/ |title=Little Dragon -Nabuma Purple Rubberband ChopNotSlop Remix |date=27 Jan 2015}} *2017: [[Moonlight (2016 film)|''Moonlight'']] Soundtrack{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2017/02/27/517502542/moonlight-director-boosts-a-chopped-and-screwed-version-of-its-soundtrack|title=Moonlight Directs Boost a Chopped and Screwed version Of Its Soundtrack}}|accessdate=27 Feb 2017{{cite web|url=http://hiphopdx.com/news/id.42525/title.moonlight-director-barry-jenkins-teams-up-with-the-chopstars-for-purple-moonlight-mixtape|title="Moonlight" Director Barry Jenkins Teams Up With The Chopstars For "Purple Moonlight" Mixtape}}|accessdate=27 Feb 2017 ==See also== * [[List of record labels]] * [[Houston hip hop]] ==References== {{reflist|1}} ==External links== * [http://chopnotslop.com OG Ron C Official Website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Candlestick, DJ}} [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:African-American people]] [[Category:American DJs]] [[Category:American hip hop record producers]] [[Category:American radio personalities]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Houston]] [[Category:Rappers from Houston]] [[Category:Southern hip hop musicians]]

revision.comment: /* Retirement */ Changed "He can be now considered" to the proper 'He can now be considered".
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Other people}} {{Infobox baseball biography |image=Dave Parker Oakland A's.jpg |caption=Parker during his time with the [[Oakland Athletics]] |name=Dave Parker |position=[[Right fielder]] / [[Designated hitter]] |bats=Left |throws=Right |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1951|6|9}} |birth_place=[[Calhoun, Mississippi]] |debutleague = MLB |debutdate=July 12 |debutyear=1973 |debutteam=Pittsburgh Pirates |finalleague = MLB |finaldate=October 2 |finalyear=1991 |finalteam=Toronto Blue Jays |statleague = MLB |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.290 |stat2label=[[Hit (baseball)|Hits]] |stat2value=2,712 |stat3label=[[Home run]]s |stat3value=339 |stat4label=[[Runs batted in]] |stat4value=1,493 |teams= *[[Pittsburgh Pirates]] ({{mlby|1973}}–{{mlby|1983}}) *[[Cincinnati Reds]] ({{mlby|1984}}–{{mlby|1987}}) *[[Oakland Athletics]] ({{mlby|1988}}–{{mlby|1989}}) *[[Milwaukee Brewers]] ({{mlby|1990}}) *[[California Angels]] ({{mlby|1991}}) *[[Toronto Blue Jays]] ({{mlby|1991}}) |highlights= *7× [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] ([[1977 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1977]], [[1979 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1979]]–[[1981 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1981]], [[1985 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1985]], [[1986 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1986]], [[1990 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1990]]) *2× [[World Series]] champion ({{wsy|1979}}, {{wsy|1989}}) * [[Major League Baseball Most Valuable Player Award|NL MVP]] (1978) *3× [[Gold Glove Award]] (1977–1979) *3× [[Silver Slugger Award]] (1985, 1986, 1990) *2× [[List of Major League Baseball batting champions|NL batting champion]] (1977, 1978) *[[List of Major League Baseball annual runs batted in leaders|NL RBI leader]] (1985) * [[Cincinnati Reds Hall of Fame and Museum|Cincinnati Reds Hall of Fame]] }} '''David Gene Parker''' (born June 9, 1951), nicknamed "'''The Cobra'''",{{cite web |url=http://www.bighairplasticgrass.com/2011/06/day-of-the-cobra.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222105157/http://www.bighairplasticgrass.com/2011/06/day-of-the-cobra.html |archivedate=February 22, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} is an American former player in [[Major League Baseball]]. He was the 1978 National League [[MVP]] and a two-time batting champion. Parker was the first professional athlete to earn an average of one million dollars per year, having signed a five-year, $5 million contract in January 1979. Parker's career achievements include 2712 hits, 339 [[home run]]s, 1493 runs batted in and a lifetime [[batting average]] of .290. Parker was also known as a solid defensive outfielder during the first half of his career, with a powerful arm, winning three consecutive [[Gold Glove]]s during his prime. From 1975 to 1979, he threw out 72 runners, including 26 in 1977. He was a baseball [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] in 1977, 1979, 1980, 1981, 1985, 1986, and 1990. In the 1979 All-Star Game, Parker showcased his defensive ability and powerful arm by throwing out [[Jim Rice]] at third base and Angels catcher [[Brian Downing]] at home. Parker also contributed an RBI on a [[sacrifice fly]] and was named the game's MVP. ==Early life== Parker grew up in Cincinnati near [[Crosley Field]], where he learned to play baseball on the stadium's parking lots. His father, Dick Parker, was a shipping clerk in a foundry.https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19780201&id=NYMqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=e1oEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3299,109912 Dave Parker attended Courter Tech High School. He has said his favorite sport was football, and he starred at tailback but injured a knee in a game during his senior year and gave up the game. Also a baseball star, one of his fondest memories is playing at [[Western Hills High School (Cincinnati, Ohio)|Western Hills High School]] (alma mater of [[Pete Rose]]), where he hit a home run that landed on the roof of a [[Frisch's]] restaurant.{{cite web |url=http://www2.cincinnati.com/blogs/recruiting/2012/03/09/dave-parker-looking-forward-to-cps-induction/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006173203/http://www2.cincinnati.com/blogs/recruiting/2012/03/09/dave-parker-looking-forward-to-cps-induction/ |archivedate=October 6, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} ==Playing career== ===Pittsburgh Pirates=== In the early 1970s, as a member of the Pirates AAA minor league ball team Charleston (WV) Charlies, Parker hit a home run that landed on a coal car on a passing train and the ball was later picked up in Columbus, Ohio."Parker Excited to Return to Charleston", ''The Charleston Gazette'', May 1, 2009. He began his major league career on July 12, 1973 with the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]], for whom he played from 1973 to 1983. At the 1977 MLB All-Star Game he became the only player in history to have worn batting helmets from two different teams—neither of them his own—in the same game, wearing a San Diego Padres helmet early on before swapping it out for a Cincinnati Reds one.Paul Lukas (July 12, 2013) "http://espn.go.com/blog/sweetspot/post/_/id/38106/uni-watch-all-star-helmet-mix-ups" In 1977, he was National League batting champion, a feat he repeated in 1978 when he was named the [[National League]]'s [[MLB Most Valuable Player Award|MVP]]. This was in spite of a collision at home plate with [[John Stearns]] during a game against the Mets on June 30, 1978, in which Parker fractured his jaw and cheekbone; he wore a specially constructed facemask in order to minimize his time away from the lineup.Paul Lukas, [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=lukas/080724 "Aggh! It's Dave Parker at the plate!,"] [[ESPN]] Page 2, July 29, 2008, accessed March 9, 2009. The Pirates rewarded him with baseball's first million-dollar-per-year contract.Derek A. Reveron, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Yn2aYTGaVQsC&pg=PA84&dq=Dave+Parker+baseball&cd=3#v=onepage&q=Dave%20Parker%20baseball&f=false "Dave Parker: Big Man, Big Bat and Baseball's Biggest Salary,"] ''Ebony'' October 1979: "the reported five=year, $5 million contract he agreed to in January."[https://books.google.com/books?id=iEIDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA48&dq=Dave+Parker+baseball&cd=10#v=onepage&q=Dave%20Parker%20baseball&f=false "Parker's $5 Million Pact Says He's Baseball's Best,"] ''Jet'' February 22, 1979, p. 48. The following year, he was an instrumental part of the Pirates' [[1979 World Series|World Series]] championship team.Dave Parker as told to George Vass, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5zMDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA79&dq=Dave+Parker+baseball&cd=2#v=onepage&q=The%20Game%20I%27ll%20Never%20Forget&f=false "The Game I'll Never Forget,"] ''Baseball Digest'' April 1985, pp. 79-80: "I've been a big influence in some pennant races. We won the division three years when I was at Pittsburgh ('74, '75 and '79), and we won the World Series in 1979." During a game in 1979, a powerful hit he made to right field was very difficult to throw into the infield, because he had "knocked the cover off the ball." One of the seams on the ball ruptured, making nearly half of the cover come loose.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebaseballzealot.com/hall-of-fame/hof-09-dave-parker |title="The Baseball Zealot", H0F '09 Dave Parker, accessed 14 Nov 2013 |publisher=Thebaseballzealot.com |date=December 9, 2008 |accessdate=June 1, 2017}} Pittsburgh fans angered by his million-dollar contract threw "nuts and bolts and bullets and batteries" at him, as pitcher [[Kent Tekulve]] stated; a typo in a news story made it appear that they threw car batteries.Mike Downey, [https://books.google.com/books?id=jzQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA30&dq=Dave+Parker+baseball&cd=1#v=snippet&q=Dave%20Parker%20left%20his%20anger&f=false "Dave Parker Left His Anger, not His Talent, in Pittsburgh: During his second season in Cincinnati, he produced some big numbers, reminiscent of his happy days with the Pirates,"] ''Baseball Digest'' November 1985, repr. from ''The Los Angeles Times'': pp. 30-31. In 1981, at a point in his career when it looked as if he would one day rank among the game's all-time greats, [[Lawrence Ritter]] and [[Donald Honig]] included him in their book ''The 100 Greatest Baseball Players of All Time''.New York: Crown, {{ISBN|0-517-54300-1}}. The authors, noting that Parker had succeeded [[Roberto Clemente]] at the position, wrote, "Someone must have a fondness for right field in Pittsburgh." Parker took after his Pirates teammate [[Willie Stargell]] in warming up in the on-deck circle with a [[sledgehammer]] (when most batters would use a simple lead-weighted bat).Rushin, Steve. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1136759/3/index.htm "Big Brew Ha-ha: Old hands Don Baylor and Dave Parker are showing the Brewers how to stay loose and win,"] ''Sports Illustrated'' (June 11, 1990). In the early 1980s, however, Parker's hitting suffered due to injuries, weight problems, and his increasing [[cocaine]] use.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1346&dat=19850912&id=KZYsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zfsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1255,4884497 "Reds Star Dave Parker Admits Cocaine Use,"] ''Lakeland Ledger'' September 12, 1985: "In his first public admission of drug use, Parker said that he bought cocaine from [Curtis] Strong and used it with him in Pittsburgh and in Philadelphia." He became one of the central figures in a drug scandal that spread through the major leagues. ===Later career=== At the end of the [[1983 Pittsburgh Pirates season|1983 season]], Parker became a free agent and signed with the [[Cincinnati Reds]]. In Cincinnati, his hometown, he returned to the form that made him an All-Star in Pittsburgh. In [[1985 Cincinnati Reds season|1985]], he enjoyed his best season since he won the 1978 MVP with a .312 batting average, 34 home runs, and 125 RBI. Parker finished second in 1985 MVP voting to [[Willie McGee]]. Following the season, Parker was among several players who testified against a dealer in the [[Pittsburgh drug trials]]. Named as "regular users", Parker and six other players were suspended for the following season. The sentences were commuted, however, in exchange for donating ten percent of their base salaries to drug-related community service, submitting to random drug testing, and contributing 100 hours of drug-related [[community service]].Cook, Ron. [http://www.post-gazette.com/pirates/200009291980bucs3.asp "The Eighties: A terrible time of trial and error,"] ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette'' (September 29, 2000).Bodley, Hal. [https://www.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/columnist/bodley/2004-03-04-bodley_x.htm "Ueberroth took action in 1986 cocaine scandal,"] ''USA Today'' (March 4, 2004). After the [[1987 Cincinnati Reds season|1987 season]], Cincinnati traded Parker to the [[Oakland Athletics]] for [[José Rijo]] and [[Tim Birtsas]]. In Oakland, Parker was able to extend his career by spending most of his time as a [[designated hitter]]. Although injuries and age caught up to him to a degree – he hit just .257 with 12 homers in 377 at-bats in [[1988 Oakland Athletics season|1988]] and .264 with 22 homers in 553 at-bats in [[1989 Oakland Athletics season|1989]] – his veteran leadership was a significant factor in the A's consecutive World Series appearances. Parker signed with the [[Milwaukee Brewers]] for the 1990 season and had a solid year as the [[1990 Milwaukee Brewers season|Brewers]]' DH with a .289 average and 21 home runs in 610 at-bats. Milwaukee opted for youth, however, at the end of the year and traded the aging Parker to the Angels for [[Dante Bichette]]. Parker's last season was 1991. He played for the [[1991 California Angels season|California Angels]] until late in the season when he was released. The [[1991 Toronto Blue Jays season|Toronto Blue Jays]] then signed him as insurance for the pennant race, and Parker hit .333 in limited action. Since he was acquired too late in the season, however, he did not qualify for inclusion on the post-season roster and thus was unable to play in the [[1991 American League Championship Series|American League Championship Series]] against the [[1991 Minnesota Twins season|Minnesota Twins]], which the Blue Jays lost in five games. Parker retired at the end of the season. ==Retirement== Parker has served as a first-base coach for the [[Anaheim Angels]], a batting coach for the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] in [[1998 St. Louis Cardinals season|1998]], and a special hitting instructor for Pittsburgh. He owned several [[Popeyes Chicken & Biscuits|Popeye's Chicken]] franchises in [[Cincinnati, Ohio|Cincinnati]]{{cite news|author=Jon Newberry|title=Franchise businesses opening doors of opportunity |url=http://cincinnati.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/stories/2007/12/31/story4.html|work=Business Courier of Cincinnati|date=December 28, 2007|accessdate=September 15, 2008}} until selling his interest in them in 2012 after 25 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn1530.com/onair/lance-mcalister-7818/former-red-cincinnati-legend-dave-parker-11548469/ |title=About Lance McAlister | Get Articles, Bio & Show Info |publisher=ESPN 1530 |date= |accessdate=June 1, 2017}} Parker never got more than 24% of votes on Hall of Fame ballots, and his 15-year Baseball Writers' Association of America eligibility was exhausted on the 2011 ballot. He can now be considered for the [[Veterans Committee]] Expansion from 2014. Along with [[Keith Hernandez]] and (until 2017) [[Tim Raines]], Parker's involvement with the [[Pittsburgh drug trials]] has been the most likely cause of his not being voted into the Hall of Fame, serving as a precursor to those listed on the [[Mitchell Report]] not being voted into the Hall of Fame due to [[Banned substances in baseball in the United States|steroid abuse]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/mlb/story/2013-01-09/baseball-hall-of-fame-vote-results-bonds-clemens-peds-biggio-morris |title=Baseball Hall of Fame 2013 vote: No candidate elected by BBWAA | MLB |publisher=Sporting News |date=January 9, 2013 |accessdate=June 1, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Langosch |first=Jenifer |url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20101118&content_id=16154154&vkey=news_mlb&c_id=mlb |title=Dave Parker gets final shot at Hall of Fame | MLB.com |publisher=Mlb.mlb.com |date= |accessdate=June 1, 2017}} Parker has had both of his knees replaced due to injuries from his playing career.[[KICU]] telecast, Oakland A's vs Chicago White Sox, August 17, 2008, per [[Dave Henderson]] In 2013, he confirmed to the ''[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]'' that he had been diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]].{{cite web|url=http://news.cincinnati.com/article/20130806/SPT04/308060096/Report-Dave-Parker-battling-Parkinson-s-disease?gcheck=1 |title=Cincinnati Enquirer | cincinnati.com |publisher=News.cincinnati.com |date= |accessdate=June 1, 2017}} He is involved in raising money to find a cure for Parkinson's disease through the Dave Parker 39 Foundation.{{cite web |url=https://www.mlb.com/news/dave-parker-doesnt-let-parkinsons-stop-him/c-221635114|title='Cobra' not letting Parkinson's hold him back|first=Bill|last=Ladson|date=March 30, 2017|accessdate=July 18, 2018|work=[[MLB.com]]}} Parker has six children. He currently resides in [[Loveland, Ohio]], near Cincinnati, with his wife, Kellye. Parker was elected to the Reds Hall of Fame Class of 2014, which also included fellow Cincinnati natives [[Ron Oester]] and [[Ken Griffey Jr.]]{{cite web|author=Press Release | |url=http://cincinnati.reds.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20131203&content_id=64366744&vkey=pr_cin&c_id=cin |title=Reds Hall of Fame Announces Class of 2014 | MLB.com |publisher=Cincinnati.reds.mlb.com |date= |accessdate=June 1, 2017}} In 2012, he was inducted into the Cincinnati Public Schools Athletic Hall of Fame. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|Baseball}} {{div col}} * [[List of Major League Baseball career home run leaders]] * [[List of Major League Baseball career hits leaders]] * [[List of Major League Baseball career doubles leaders]] * [[List of Major League Baseball career runs scored leaders]] * [[List of Major League Baseball career runs batted in leaders]] * [[List of Major League Baseball annual runs batted in leaders]] * [[List of Major League Baseball batting champions]] * [[List of Major League Baseball annual doubles leaders]] * [[List of Major League Baseball career stolen bases leaders]] * [[List of Major League Baseball career total bases leaders]] * [[List of St. Louis Cardinals coaches]] * [[List of sportspeople sanctioned for doping offences]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Baseballstats|mlb=|espn=|br=p/parkeda01|fangraphs=1010000|cube=dave-parker|brm=parker003dav}}, or [http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/P/Pparkd001.htm Retrosheet], or [http://lesterslegends.com/?p=348 Lesters Legends], or [http://www.purapelota.com/lvbp/mostrar.php?id=parkdav001 Pura Pelota (Venezuelan Winter League)] {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-ach}}}} {{succession box|before=[[Pete Rose]]

page.title: Disappearance of Louise and Charmian Faulkner

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Louise Faulkner | birth_name = Louise Yvonne Faulkner | birth_place = [[Colac, Victoria]], Australia | birth_date = 7 April 1937 | disappeared_date = April 1980 (age 43) | disappeared_place = [[St Kilda, Victoria]], Australia }} {{Infobox person | name = Charmian Faulkner | birth_name = Charmian Christabel Alexis Faulkner | birth_date = 30 October 1977 | disappeared_date = April 1980 (age 2) | disappeared_place = [[St Kilda, Victoria]], Australia | mother = Louise Faulkner | father = Uncertain, possibly George Sutherland<ref name="TheAge">{{cite news|last1=Berry|first1=Jamie|title=Mother, daughter 'met with foul play'|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/mother-daughter-met-with-foul-play/2006/08/14/1155407742410.html|accessdate=10 October 2017|publisher=The Age|date=15 Aug 2006}}</ref> }} '''Louise Yvonne Faulkner''' (born 7 April 1937) and '''Charmian Christabel Alexis Faulkner''' (born 30 October 1977) were a mother and daughter who [[Missing person|went missing]] from [[St Kilda, Victoria]], Australia, in 1980. {{As of|2014}}, no-one has been charged over the disappearance and no bodies have been found.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/daughter-still-hopes-for-the-call-to-unlock-a-34yearold-murder-mystery-20140801-zzbxt.html |title= Daughter still hopes for the call to unlock a 34-year-old murder mystery |date=2 August 2014 |first=Tammy |last=Mills |newspaper=[[The Age]] |accessdate=24 July 2016}}</ref>
== Background == Louise was born on 7 April 1937 in [[Colac, Victoria]] and was the youngest of three children.{{Citation needed|date=July 2016}} Charmian was born on 30 October 1977.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSob=c&GSmid=47914829&GRid=141867548& |title=Charmian Faulkner |first=Alyssa |last=McIntosh |work=Find A Grave Memorial |id=141867548 |date=27 January 2015 |accessdate=24 July 2016}}</ref>
== Last confirmed sighting == Whilst residing at Acland St, St. Kilda, Louise Faulkner developed a friendship with Corrine Wylde, a neighbour in the same block of flats. On 25 April 1980, [[Anzac Day]] in Australia, Louise and Charmian attended a first birthday party for Wylde's son. Faulkner told Wylde that she was going to visit her boyfriend in [[Gippsland]]. The following day, Wylde saw the two Faulkners get into a white [[Ute (vehicle)|ute]] with an older man. This was the last confirmed sighting of either of them. Louise Faulkner was aged 43 and Charmian was two at the time of their disappearance. The only suspect was her lover 60 year old George Sutherland whom Louise Faulkner named as Charmian's father.<ref name = "SMH1">{{Cite web | url = http://www.smh.com.au//breaking-news-national/police-offer-reward-for-mum-mystery-20101006-167my.html | work =[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | title = Police offer reward for 'mum mystery' | first = Greg | last = Roberts | date = 6 October 2010 | accessdate = 24 July 2016}}</ref>
== Police investigation == On 9 June 1980 preliminary investigations of the disappearances began. Inquiries were conducted over the following 12 months with friends and associates of Louise.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=kqworumadRcC&pg=PA231&lpg=PA231&q=george%20sutherland%20faulkner |accessdate=24 July 2016 |pages=220–235 |title=Badlands: Australia's 13 Most Intriguing True Murders |last=Houlihan |first=Liam |date= 1 August 2010 |publisher=Melbourne University Publishing|isbn=9780522859768 }}</ref>
== Coronial inquest == In August 2006 a [[Inquest|coronial inquest]] was held into the disappearance and death of Louise and Charmian Faulkner and found that the pair were probably murdered.<ref name = "SMH1" /> The inquest was re-convened in 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/daughter-haunted-by-28-year-mystery/story-e6frf7jo-1111115644627 |title=Daughter haunted by 28-year mystery |newspaper=Herald Sun |date=26 February 2008 |author=Dina Rosendorff |accessdate=24 July 2016}}</ref> On that occasion the coroner ruled the deaths foul play, but said there was not enough evidence to link anyone to the killings.<ref name = "ABC1">[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (18 March 2008). [http://www.abc.net.au/news/2008-03-18/missing-pairs-death-ruled-foul-play/1076070 "Missing pair's death ruled 'foul play'"]. Retrieved 22 May 2016.</ref>
==See also== * [[Cold case (criminology)|Cold case]] * [[Crime in Melbourne]] * [[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Faulkner, Louise And Charmian}} [[Category:1980 deaths]] [[Category:1980 in Australia]] [[Category:1980s missing person cases]] [[Category:Crime in Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:History of Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Missing people]] [[Category:Missing person cases in Australia]] [[Category:Missing Australian children]]

{{Infobox CanadianMP | honorific-prefix =[[The Honourable]] |name = Dominic LeBlanc | honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=CAN|PC|MP|size=100%}} | image = Dominic LeBlanc.jpg | caption = Dominic LeBlanc 2009 | office = [[Minister of Intergovernmental Affairs, Northern Affairs and Internal Trade]] | term_start = July 18, 2018 | predecessor =[[Justin Trudeau]] (Intergovernmental Affairs and Youth)
[[Carolyn Bennett]] (Northern Affairs) | primeminister =[[Justin Trudeau]] | term_end = | office1 = [[President of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada]] | term_start1 = July 18, 2018 | term_end1 = | predecessor1 = [[Karina Gould]] | successor1 = | office2 = 50th [[Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard]] | term_start2 = May 31, 2016 | predecessor2 =[[Hunter Tootoo]] | successor2 =[[Jonathan Wilkinson (politician)|Jonathan Wilkinson]] | primeminister2 =[[Justin Trudeau]] | term_end2 = July 18, 2018 | office3 = [[Leader of the Government in the House of Commons (Canada)|Leader of the Government in the House of Commons]] | primeminister3 = [[Justin Trudeau]] | term_start3 = November 4, 2015 | term_end3 = August 19, 2016 | predecessor3 = [[Peter Van Loan]] | successor3 = [[Bardish Chagger]] | riding4 =[[Beauséjour (electoral district)|Beauséjour]] | parliament4 = Canadian | term_start4 = November 27, 2000 | predecessor4 = [[Angela Vautour]] | term_end4 = | successor4 = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1967|12|14}} | birth_place = [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], Canada | death_date = | death_place = | profession = Lawyer | party = [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] | residence = [[Moncton|Moncton, New Brunswick]] | footnotes = | spouse = Jolène Richard | religion =[[Roman Catholic]]http://www2.macleans.ca/tag/dominic-leblanc/page/3/ | website = [https://www.ourcommons.ca/Parliamentarians/en/members/Dominic-LeBlanc(1813)/Roles/ Dominic LeBlanc] }} '''Dominic A. LeBlanc''' {{post-nominals|country=CAN|PC|MP}} (born December 14, 1967), is a Canadian lawyer and politician. He has been the member of parliament for the [[New Brunswick]] riding of [[Beauséjour (electoral district)|Beauséjour]] since 2000. Since July 2018, he has been serving as [[Minister of Intergovernmental Affairs, Northern Affairs and Internal Trade|Minister of Intergovernmental Affairs, Northern affairs and Internal Trade]]. LeBlanc is the son of former Member of Parliament, [[Senate of Canada|Senator]] and [[Governor General of Canada]], [[Roméo LeBlanc]].{{cite web|url=http://www.macleans.ca/politics/ottawa/romeo-leblanc-1927-2009/|title=Romeo LeBlanc, 1927-2009|work=Maclean's|date=June 24, 2009|accessdate=2015-05-25}} LeBlanc ran for leadership of Liberal Party in 2008 but dropped out of [[Liberal Party of Canada leadership election, 2009|the race]] to endorse [[Michael Ignatieff]], who was later acclaimed leader. With the resignation of Ignatieff after the [[Canadian federal election, 2011|2011 federal election]] LeBlanc was considered a likely candidate in [[Liberal Party of Canada leadership election, 2013|the race]] to succeed him as party leader, but declined on running.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/leblanc-eyes-liberal-leadership-1.1117264|title=LeBlanc eyes Liberal leadership|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=2011-05-03|accessdate=2018-05-16}}{{cite news|title=Justin Trudeau's leadership bid backed by LeBlanc|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/justin-trudeau-s-leadership-bid-backed-by-leblanc-1.1299230|accessdate=May 16, 2018|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=October 5, 2012}} On November 4, 2015, he was appointed the [[Leader of the Government in the House of Commons]] in the present [[Cabinet of Canada|Cabinet]], headed by [[Justin Trudeau]]. On May 31, 2016, upon the resignation of [[Hunter Tootoo]] from the Ministry, LeBlanc also assumed the role of [[Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard]]. On August 19, 2016, LeBlanc was replaced by [[Bardish Chagger]] as [[Leader of the Government in the House of Commons]].{{cite web|title=Bardish Chagger adds government House leader to small business, tourism duties|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/cabinet-shuffle-house-learder-1.3728243|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=19 August 2016}} On July 18, 2018, LeBlanc was shuffled from the role of [[Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard]] to the role of [[Minister of Intergovernmental Affairs, Northern Affairs and Internal Trade]]. ==Early life and education== LeBlanc was born in [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], to [[Roméo LeBlanc]] and Joslyn "Lyn" Carter. As a child, he baby-sat [[Justin Trudeau|Justin]], [[Alexandre Trudeau|Alexandre]], and [[Michel Trudeau]], the children of then-Prime Minister [[Pierre Trudeau]]. He has remained friends with Justin Trudeau, with whom he is currently serving with in the House of Commons, and endorsed [[Liberal Party of Canada leadership election, 2013|his candidacy for Liberal leader]] in 2012. LeBlanc attended [[Lisgar Collegiate Institute]] for high school.{{cite web | url=https://ottawacitizen.com/news/national/dominic-leblanc-is-trudeaus-go-to-guy-heres-why | title=Dominic LeBlanc is Trudeau's go-to guy. Here's why | publisher=[[Ottawa Citizen]] | date=1 December 2015 | accessdate=1 December 2015 | author=Kennedy, Mark}} He earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in political science from the [[University of Toronto]] ([[Trinity College, Toronto|Trinity College]]), a [[Bachelor of Laws]] degree from the [[University of New Brunswick]], and then attended [[Harvard Law School]], where he obtained his [[Master of Laws]] degree. Prior to being elected to the House of Commons, LeBlanc was a Barrister and Solicitor with Clark Drummie in [[Shediac]] and [[Moncton]]. From 1993-1996, LeBlanc was a Special Advisor to the [[Jean Chrétien|Prime Minister Jean Chrétien]]. He is the son of the former Governor General of Canada, The Right Honourable Roméo LeBlanc, who had previously been the Member of Parliament for Westmorland-Kent from 1972 to 1984, and then a Senator from 1984 to 1994.[http://dominicleblanc.liberal.ca/en/biography Biography] LeBlanc is an [[Acadian]]. ==Political career== LeBlanc is member of the [[Liberal Party of Canada]] in the [[House of Commons of Canada]], representing the riding of [[Beauséjour (electoral district)|Beauséjour]] in [[New Brunswick]]. LeBlanc first ran in that riding in 1997,{{cite web|url=http://votes.canada.com/fed97/970419_candid1.html|title=Governor General's son wins Liberal nomination|work=Southam Newspapers|date=April 19, 1997|accessdate=2015-05-25|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990225095522/http://votes.canada.com/fed97/970419_candid1.html|archivedate=February 25, 1999}} losing to [[New Democratic Party]] candidate, [[Angela Vautour]].{{cite web|url=http://www.herald.ns.ca/fedelect/97archive/jun4/970604159.html|title=Beausejour, not Bay Street|work=The Chronicle Herald|date=June 4, 1997|accessdate=2015-05-25|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010727102645/http://www.herald.ns.ca/fedelect/97archive/jun4/970604159.html|archivedate=July 27, 2001}} During that race there were accusations of political patronage as LeBlanc's father was the sitting viceroy, and there was criticism that the Governor General had a series of events planned in New Brunswick the very week that the Prime Minister dropped the [[Writ of election|election writs]].{{Citation|last=Fidelis |title=The LeBlanc Years: A Frank Assessment |journal=Canadian Monarchist News |volume=Autumn 1999 |publisher=Monarchist League of Canada |location=Toronto |year=1999 |url=http://www.monarchist.ca/cmn/1999/leblanc.htm |accessdate=March 2, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090708032551/http://www.monarchist.ca/cmn/1999/leblanc.htm |archivedate=July 8, 2009 }}{{Citation| last=Martin| first=Don| title=Jean is now least boring G-Gever| newspaper=National Post| date=May 28, 2009| url=https://nationalpost.com/opinion/columnists/story.html?id=f1e51d92-758b-4d2a-a554-6572d09186b1| accessdate=October 23, 2014| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141023064959/http://www.nationalpost.com/opinion/columnists/story.html?id=f1e51d92-758b-4d2a-a554-6572d09186b1| archivedate=October 23, 2014| df=}}{{Citation |last=Smith |first=David E. |year=1999 |publication-date=2007 |title=The Republican Option in Canada: Past and Present |editor-last=Jackson |editor-first=Michael D. |periodical=Canadian Monarchist News |volume=Autumn-Winter 2007 |issue=27 |page=12 |place=Toronto-Buffalo-London |publication-place=Toronto |publisher=Monarchist League of Canada |url=http://www.monarchist.ca/cmn/2007/AutumnWinter_2007_CMN.pdf |accessdate=July 26, 2009 |archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090708031338/http://www.monarchist.ca/cmn/2007/AutumnWinter_2007_CMN.pdf |archive-date=July 8, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}{{Citation |last=Boyce |first=Peter |year=2008 |publication-date=October 2009 |editor-last=Jackson |editor-first=Michael D. |title=The Senior Realms of the Queen |periodical=Canadian Monarchist News |volume=Autumn 2009 |issue=30 |page=10 |place=Sydney |publication-place=Toronto |publisher=Monarchist League of Canada |url=http://www.monarchist.ca/cmn/2009/Autumn_2009_CMN.pdf |access-date=October 22, 2009 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091229100400/http://www.monarchist.ca/cmn/2009/Autumn_2009_CMN.pdf |archive-date=December 29, 2009 }} In 2000 LeBlanc once again ran against Vautour, who had [[crossed the floor]] and was a [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservative]], and was elected.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/liberals-gain-three-seats-in-nb-1.239370|title=Liberals gain three seats in NB|work=CBC News|date=November 28, 2000|accessdate=2015-05-25}} LeBlanc has been re-elected in the [[Canadian federal election, 2004|2004]] (where he faced Vautour for the third time), [[Canadian federal election, 2006|2006]], [[Canadian federal election, 2008|2008]], [[Canadian federal election, 2011|2011]] and 2015 federal elections. ===Chrétien and Martin governments=== During the Liberal Party's time in power LeBlanc served as [[Parliamentary Secretary]] to the [[Minister of National Defence (Canada)|Minister of National Defence]], from January 13, 2003, to December 11, 2003, and was the chair of the Atlantic Caucus. On July 10, 2004, he was sworn-in as a Member of the Privy Council for Canada and appointed Parliamentary Secretary to the [[Leader of the Government in the House of Commons (Canada)|Leader of the Government in the House of Commons]] and Deputy Chief Government Whip. He has served on the Special Committee on Non-Medical Use of Drugs, and the Standing Committees on Fisheries and Oceans, Transport and Government Operations, National Defence and Veterans Affairs, and Public Accounts, Procedures and House Affairs, and International Trade. ===In opposition=== In January 2006, he was named Official Opposition critic for international trade and later that year he was co-chair of the [[Liberal Party of Canada leadership election, 2006|2006 Liberal Party leadership convention]] in [[Montreal]]. In January 2007, he was named by the Honourable [[Stéphane Dion]], Vice Chair - Liberal Party of Canada Policy and Platform Committee and In October of that year, he was named Official Opposition critic for intergovernmental affairs. In January 2009, he was named by the Honourable [[Michael Ignatieff]] as the critic for justice and attorney general. Before the return of Parliament in September 2010, Ignatieff shuffled his Shadow Cabinet and appointed LeBlanc as the Liberal critic for national defence.[https://archive.is/20100918120619/http://www.nationalpost.com/news/Ignatieff+shuffles+shadow+cabinet/3491323/story.html .Ignatieff shuffles shadow cabinet] Following LeBlanc's re-election in the 2011 federal election, interim Liberal leader [[Bob Rae]] appointed LeBlanc as the Liberal Party's Foreign Affairs Critic. ====2008 leadership bid==== On October 27, 2008, LeBlanc was the first candidate to officially announce his intention to seek the leadership of the Liberal party to replace Stéphane Dion. Former leadership candidates Michael Ignatieff and Bob Rae came forward shortly after LeBlanc's announcement.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/leblanc-seeks-manley-tests-liberal-support/article662227/|publisher=Globe and Mail|author=Brian Laghi and Omar El Akkad|date=2008-10-27|accessdate=2015-05-25|title=LeBlanc seeks, Manley tests Liberal support}} His supporters included top staffers in the prime minister's office under [[Jean Chrétien]], such as his former chief of staff [[Percy Downe]], and [[Tim Murphy (Canadian politician)|Tim Murphy]], chief of staff under [[Paul Martin]]. Some senior organizers in [[Gerard Kennedy]]'s 2006 leadership bid were also with LeBlanc.[http://timestranscript.canadaeast.com/newstoday/article/463705 Beausejour MP to run for federal Liberal leadership, wants to be a voice for middle-class, younger generation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110828232530/http://timestranscript.canadaeast.com/newstoday/article/463705 |date=August 28, 2011 }} On December 8, 2008, LeBlanc announced he was dropping out of the leadership race because he felt a leader needed to be put in place as soon as possible and that he was throwing his support behind Ignatieff. The next day Rae dropped out of the race and Ignatieff was acclaimed leader when Dion stepped down.{{cite news|url = http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20081208/dion_coalition_081208/20081208?hub=TopStories|publisher = CTV|date = 2008-12-08|accessdate = 2008-12-08|title = Dion to step aside; LeBlanc supports Ignatieff|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081209064032/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20081208/dion_coalition_081208/20081208?hub=TopStories|archivedate = 2008-12-09|df = }}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/rae-bows-out-offers-unqualified-support-for-ignatieff-as-liberal-leader-1.732354|title=Rae bows out, offers 'unqualified' support for Ignatieff as Liberal leader|work=CBC News|date=December 9, 2008|accessdate=2015-05-25}} ====2011-2015==== LeBlanc retained his seat in the [[Canadian federal election, 2011|2011 election]], while the Liberals dropped down to third place in the House of Commons. Regarding the race for the leadership of the Liberal Party, LeBlanc, a prospective leadership candidate, puts it, the next leader needs to commit 10 to 15 years of his or her life "occupied exclusively" with rebuilding the Liberal party and winning elections.{{cite web|title=The Ottawa Citizen - Liberals set to lay out latest leadership race rules|url=https://ottawacitizen.com/news/Liberals+latest+leadership+race+rules/7200075/story.html|work=The Ottawa Citizen|publisher=The Ottawa Citizen|accessdate=September 12, 2012}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} === Trudeau government === On November 4, 2015, he was appointed the [[Leader of the Government in the House of Commons]] in the present [[Cabinet of Canada|Cabinet]], headed by [[Justin Trudeau]]. On May 31, 2016, upon the resignation of [[Hunter Tootoo]] from the Ministry, LeBlanc also became the [[Minister of Fisheries, Oceans, and the Canadian Coast Guard|Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard]]. His father had previously held the equivalent position under Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/hunter-tootoo-resigns-1.3609915|title=Hunter Tootoo resigns as fisheries minister, leaves Liberal caucus|last=|first=|date=May 31, 2016|work=[[CBC News]]|access-date=May 31, 2016|via=}} On August 19, 2016, Leblanc was replaced as [[Leader of the Government in the House of Commons]] by [[Bardish Chagger]]. He retained the post of [[Minister of Fisheries, Oceans, and the Canadian Coast Guard|Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard]]. On July 18, 2018, Leblanc was shuffled from [[Minister of Fisheries, Oceans, and the Canadian Coast Guard|Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard]] to [[Minister of Intergovernmental Affairs]].https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/trudeau-cabinet-shuffle-2018-1.4749976 On September 12, 2018 Canada's Ethics Commissioner Mario Dion found LeBlanc broke conflict of interest rules when he awarded a lucrative Arctic surf clam licence to a company linked to his wife's cousin in February 2018.[https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/leblanc-conflict-of-interest-fishing-licence-1.4820213 ] ====Cabinet positions==== {{s-start}} {{Canadian federal ministry navigational box header |ministry=29}}
