/* top */[[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/PrimeBOT 29|Task 29]] - removal of deprecated parameters from [[Template:infobox person]] (+ genfixes)

The entire sections 'US–China military and intelligence ties', 'Role in the Stingers for Afghanistan Decision' and 'Studies of China and the Pentagon's Annual Report' are copied verbatim from Pillsbury's own website. For that reason the people cited in those sections cannot be seen as neutral commentators, in fact there is no independent viewpoint presented at all.
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Lead rewrite|reason=lede promotes title subject (e.g., book) rather than summarising article, presents content unsupported by sources (in main body/lede)|date=November 2018}} {{BLP sources|date=December 2018|reason=The entire sections 'US–China military and intelligence ties', 'Role in the Stingers for Afghanistan Decision' and 'Studies of China and the Pentagon's Annual Report' are copied verbatim from Pillsbury's own website. For that reason the people cited in those sections cannot be seen as neutral commentators, in fact there is no independent viewpoint presented at all}} {{page numbers needed|date=November 2018}} }} {{Infobox person |name = Michael Pillsbury |image = Michael_Pillsbury_Official_Photo.jpeg |image_size = 100px |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|2|8|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[California]], US |death_date = |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = |occupation = Consultant at US Department of Defense (2003–present) |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |nationality = |education = [[Stanford University]] (BA in History)
[[Columbia University]] ( PhD) }} '''Michael Pillsbury''' (born February 8, 1945) is the American Director of the Center on Chinese Strategy, [[Hudson Institute]], [[Washington, D.C.]], from 2014. He is the author of three books on China. The most recent one, ''The Hundred-Year Marathon'', is an international bestseller{{cn|date=November 2018}} and was number one on the ''[[Washington Post]]'' list,February 15, 2015.{{full|date=November 2018}} and a selection of the Commander, U.S. Special Operations Command, Commanders Reading List, in 2017,{{cn|date=November 2018}} with Korean, Japanese, Taiwan-Chinese, PRC-Chinese, Hindi, and Mongolian editions also published.{{cn|date=November 2018}} On September 26, 2018 U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] described Michael Pillsbury as "the leading authority on China.”{{cite news|first=David|last=Tweed|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-27/trump-identifies-the-leading-authority-on-china-who-is-he|title=This Is the Man Trump Described as ‘The Leading Authority on China’|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=September 27, 2018|page=A1|accessdate=September 27, 2018}} On November 30, 2018 The New York Times, Politico and Bloomberg articles asserted Michael Pillsbury's importance of being one of Trump's top advisers on China.”{{cite news|first=Lexey|last=Swall|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/30/us/politics/trump-china-trade-xi-michael-pillsbury.html|title=A China Hawk Gains Prominence as Trump Confronts Xi on Trade’|work=[[The New York Times|The New York Times]]|date=November 30, 2018|page=A1|accessdate=November 30, 2018}},{{cite news|first=Andrew|last=Mayeda|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-11-28/there-s-no-cold-war-with-china-says-trump-s-hawkish-adviser|title=There's No Cold War With China, Says Trump's Hawkish Adviser’|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=November 28, 2018|page=A1|accessdate=November 28, 2018}},{{cite news|first=Ben|last=SCHRECKINGER |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/11/30/trump-china-xi-jinping-g20-michael-pillsbury-1034610|title= The China hawk who captured Trump's 'very, very large brain'’|work=[[POLITICO|POLITICO]]|date=November 30, 2018|page=A1|accessdate=November 30, 2018}} ==Career== During the Reagan administration, Pillsbury was the Assistant Under Secretary of Defense for Policy Planning and responsible for implementation of the program of covert aid known as the [[Reagan Doctrine]]. In 1975–76, while an analyst at the [[RAND Corporation]], Pillsbury published articles in ''[[Foreign Policy (magazine)|Foreign Policy]]'' and ''[[International Security]]'' recommending that the United States establish intelligence and military ties with China. The proposal, publicly commended by [[Ronald Reagan]], [[Henry Kissinger]], and [[James Schlesinger]], later became US policy during the Carter and Reagan administrations. Pillsbury served on the staff of four US Senate Committees from 1978–1984 and 1986–1991. As a staff member, Pillsbury drafted the Senate Labor Committee version of the legislation that enacted the [[US Institute of Peace]] in 1984.{{cite journal|first=Mary E.|last=Montgomery|title=Working for Peace While Preparing for War: The Creation of the United States Institute of Peace|journal=Journal of Peace Research|volume=40|issue=4|year=2003|pages=479–496|doi=10.1177/00223433030404007}} He also assisted in drafting the legislation to create the [[National Endowment for Democracy]] and the annual requirement for a DOD report on Chinese military power. In 1992, under President [[George H. W. Bush]], Pillsbury was Special Assistant for Asian Affairs in the [[Office of the Secretary of Defense]], reporting to [[Andrew W. Marshall]], Director of Net Assessment. Pillsbury is a member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] and the [[International Institute for Strategic Studies]]. In 2015, a former CIA Director revealed that a book called ''The Hundred-Year Marathon'' "is based on work Michael Pillsbury did that landed him the CIA Director's Exceptional Performance Award." The official website has declassified documents and photos that illustrate the book. Pillsbury played a role in three Presidential actions: ===US–China military and intelligence ties=== Pillsbury participated in President [[Jimmy Carter]]'s decision in 1979–80, as modified by President Reagan in 1981, to initiate military and intelligence ties with China.{{cite book|first=James|last=Mann|title=About Face: A History of America's Curious Relationship with China, from Nixon to Clinton|publisher=Knopf|year=1998|isbn=978-0-679-76861-6|authorlink=James Mann (writer)}}{{page needed|date=November 2018}}{{cite book|first=Banning|last=Garrett|title=The China Card and its Origins|publisher=Brandeis University doctoral dissertation}}{{page needed|date=November 2018}}{{page needed|date=November 2018}} According to [[Raymond L. Garthoff]], "Michael Pillsbury first floated the idea of arms sales and broad range of American military security relationships with China in a much-discussed article in ''Foreign Policy'' in the fall of 1975. Not known then was that Pillsbury had been conducting secret talks with Chinese officials … his reports were circulated to a dozen or so top officials of the NSC, Department of Defense and Department of State as secret documents."{{cite book|first=Raymond L.|last=Garthoff|title=Détente and Confrontation: American-Soviet Relations from Nixon to Reagan|publisher=Brookings Institution|year=1983|isbn=978-0-8157-3044-6|authorlink=Raymond L. Garthoff}}{{rp|696}} According to the book ''US–China Cold War Collaboration, 1971–1989'', "The man spearheading the effort was not a public official, and enjoyed deniability. Michael Pillsbury, a China analyst at the RAND Corporation… spent the summer of 1973 secretly meeting PLA officers stationed under diplomatic cover at China's UN mission… The DoD managed Pillsbury. Pillsbury filed a report, L-32, in March 1974… L-32 was a seminal paper on which subsequent US-PRC military cooperation blossomed."{{cite book|first=Mahmud|last=Ali|title=US-China Cold War Collaboration, 1971–1989|publisher=Routledge|year=2005|isbn=978-0-415-35819-4}}{{rp|81}} [[James Mann (writer)|James Mann]] wrote, "Outward appearances indicate that Pillsbury may have been working with American intelligence agencies from the very start of his relationship with General Zhang… In the fall of 1973, Pillsbury submitted a classified memo suggesting the novel idea that the United States might establish a military relationship with China… This was the genesis of the ideas of a 'China card,' the notion that the United States might use China to gain Cold War advantage over the Soviet Union. The idea would eventually come to dominate American thinking about the new relationship with China."{{rp|58–59}} ===Stingers for Afghanistan decision=== Pillsbury participated in President Reagan's decision in 1986 to order the CIA to arm the Afghan resistance with [[Stinger missiles]]. According to the UN Undersecretary General who negotiated the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, "Initially, the Stinger campaign was spearheaded by Undersecretary of Defense for Policy [[Fred Ikle]] and his aggressive Coordinator for Afghan Affairs, Michael Pillsbury… The Stinger proponents won their victory in the face of overwhelming bureaucratic resistance that persisted until the very end of the struggle."{{cite book|last=Cordovez|first=Diego|title=Out of Afghanistan: The Inside Story of the Soviet Withdrawal|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1995|isbn=978-0-19-506294-6}}{{rp|195}} Mann wrote, "For Michael Pillsbury, the covert operations in Afghanistan represented the fulfillment of the decade-old dream of American military cooperation with China… To help him win the argument, Pillsbury made use of his China connections."{{rp|137–139}} [[George Crile III|George Crile]] stated in ''[[Charlie Wilson's War: The Extraordinary Story of the Largest Covert Operation in History|Charlie Wilson's War]]'' that, "Ironically, neither [[Gust Avrakotos|[Gust] Avrakotos]] nor [[Charles Wilson (Texas politician)|[Charlie] Wilson]] was directly involved in the decision and claims any credit."{{cite book|last=Crile|first=George|title=Charlie Wilson's War: The Extraordinary Story of the Largest Covert Operation in History|publisher=Atlantic Monthly Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0-87113-854-5|authorlink=George Crile III}}{{rp|419}}{{cite book|first=Philip|last=Heymann|title=Living the Policy Process|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2008|isbn=978-0-19-533539-2|authorlink=Philip Heymann}}{{page needed|date=November 2018}}{{cite book|first1=Milt|last1=Bearden|first2=James|last2=Risen|title=The Main Enemy: The Inside Story of the CIA's Final Showdown with the KGB|publisher=Ballantine|year=2004|isbn=978-0-345-47250-2|pages=211–212}}{{cite book|first=Steve|last=Coll|title=Ghost Wars: The Secret History of the CIA, Afghanistan and bin Laden|publisher=Penguin|year=2004|isbn=978-1-59420-007-6|authorlink=Steve Coll}}{{page needed|date=November 2018}}{{cite book|first=Steve|last=Coll|title=The Bin Ladens: An Arabian Family in the American Century|year=2009|publisher= Penguin|isbn=978-1-59420-164-6|authorlink=Steve Coll}}{{page needed|date=November 2018}}{{cite report|first=Kirsten|last=Lundberg|title=Politics of a Covert Action: The US, the Mujahideen, and the Stinger Missile|publisher=Kennedy School of Government Case Program. C15-99-1546.0|year=1999|url=}}{{page needed|date=November 2018}}{{cite web|author1=Sullivan, Tim |author2=Singer, Matt |author3=Rawson, Jessica |title=What Were Policymakers' and Intelligence Services' Respective Roles in the Decision to Deploy Stinger Missiles to the Anticommunist Afghan Mujahedin During the Rebels' Struggle with the Soviet Union? |url=http://www12.georgetown.edu/students/organizations/nscs/capitalscholar/Fall2006/Soviet%20Union%20and%20Stinger%20Missiles.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101218145219/http://www12.georgetown.edu/students/organizations/nscs/capitalscholar/Fall2006/Soviet%20Union%20and%20Stinger%20Missiles.htm |archivedate=2010-12-18 |df= }} Harvard University's JFK School of Government published what it called the first case study of how covert action policy is made and describes the role of Michael Pillsbury.{{rp|24}} According to ''Charlie Wilson's War'', "The moving force in this group was an engaging, well-born conservative intellectual named Mike Pillsbury, then serving as the Pentagon's deputy undersecretary in charge of overseeing covert programs. Pillsbury, a former Senate staffer and China expert, had been an early believer in the program…"{{rp|415–416}} According to [[Philip Heymann]] in his 2008 book ''Living the Policy Process'', "A policy player such as Michael Pillsbury may have absorbed many of the critical rules of the game of shared policy choice without even thinking of them as rules."{{page needed|date=November 2018}} Heymann wrote that "providing Stinger missiles was obviously of such importance or political prominence that the President would want to decide. This decision is obviously of that character for several reasons. If approved, we may be furnishing a terrifying weapon to a present or future enemy. There is a small chance that we will encourage dangerous forms of retaliation by the Soviet Union. Even the shift from a "plausibly deniable" covert action to the open support of a guerrilla force fighting the Soviet Union would raise issues in Congress that the President would want to consider in light of his staff's advice."{{page needed|date=November 2018}} Pillsbury worked through the secret Planning and Coordination Group. Heymann wrote, "This committee was secret, and public details about it are sketchy… The covert action committee met every three to four weeks. Its existence was not officially acknowledged, although such a committee had operated in every administration since Eisenhower. In the Kennedy administration, for example, it was known as the Forty Committee. Any information on covert actions was protected under a compartmentalized security system given the name VEIL."{{page needed|date=November 2018}} According to [[Steve Coll]], in 1985–1986 [[Osama Bin Laden]] also wanted US weapons including the Stinger missiles. Coll wrote, "Michael Pillsbury flies to the Afghan frontier to review training facilities used by two Afghan warlords, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar and Abdul Rasul Sayyaf… Bin Laden family head [[Salem bin Laden]] asks the Pentagon to supply anti-aircraft missiles to Arab volunteers fighting in the Soviet-Afghan War. The request is made on behalf of Salem's brother Osama [Bin Laden], who is establishing a semi-autonomous group of Arab volunteers outside the direct control of local Afghan commanders and will set up a camp just for Arabs later this year… Later research will indicate that there is no formal decision by the Reagan administration not to supply the missiles or other equipment to the Arab volunteers. Pentagon official Michael Pillsbury will later say he was not aware of any such decision, but if such a decision had been taken, he would have been aware of it."{{rp|287}} ===Studies of China and the Pentagon's annual report=== In 1997–2007, Pillsbury published research reports and two books on China's view of future warfare. According to the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' in 2005, Pillsbury's findings were added to the reports the Secretary of Defense sent to Congress on Chinese military power in 2002–2005.{{cite news|first=Neil|last=King|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB112613947626134749|format=Fee required|title=Secret Weapon: Inside Pentagon, A Scholar Shapes Views of China|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=September 8, 2005|page=A1|accessdate=June 23, 2009}}{{cite news|title=The Pillsbury Factor|work=The Oriental Economist|date=August 2002}} In 2003, Pillsbury signed a nonpartisan report of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] task force on Chinese military power. The task force found that China is pursuing a deliberate course of military modernization, but is at least two decades behind the United States in terms of military technology and capability. The task force report stated it was a "nonpartisan approach to measuring the development of Chinese military power."{{cite book|last=Segal|first=Adam|title=Chinese Military Power Independent Task Force Report|publisher=[[Council on Foreign Relations]]|year=2003|isbn=978-0-87609-330-6}}{{page needed|date=November 2018}} He has discussed the threat the people's republic of China poses to the United States of America with [[Tucker Carlson]].{{cite web|url=https://www.hudson.org/research/14318-the-china-threat|title=The China Threat|first=Michael|last=Pillsbury|website=Hudson.org|accessdate=7 November 2018}} ==Criticism== Pillsbury's scholarship has been questioned by ''[[Washington Monthly]]'' assistant editor Soyoung Ho, in his article "Panda Slugger, the dubious scholarship of Michael Pillsbury, the China hawk with Rumsfeld's ear", published in the July/August issue in 2006.{{cite web|last1=Ho |first1=Soyoung |title=Panda Slugger, the dubious scholarship of Michael Pillsbury, the China hawk with Rumsfeld's ear. |url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2006/0607.ho1.html |work=Washington Monthly |accessdate=3 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214060701/http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2006/0607.ho1.html |archivedate=14 February 2015 |df= }} ==VOA commentator== Since May 2014, Pillsbury has been a frequent guest on [[Voice of America]] Chinese providing opinions and participating in discussion in Mandarin Chinese typically on defense-related issues. ==Government positions== * Consultant at [[US Department of Defense]] 2004–present * Senior Research Advisor at US-China Economic and Security Review Commission 2003–2004 * Policy Advisory Group at United States Department of Defense 2001–2003 * Visiting Research Fellow at [[National Defense University]], 1997–2000 * Special Government Employee at US Department of Defense (Defense Science Board) 1998–2000 * Research Consultant at [[US Agency for International Development]] 1991–1995 * Special Assistant to Director of Net Assessment US Department of Defense 1992–1993 * Congressional Afghan Task Force Senate Staff Coordinator at [[US Senate]] 1986–1990 * Assistant Under Secretary for Policy Planning at US Department of Defense 1984–1986 * Professional Staff at US Senate 1978–1981 * Acting Director, Arms Control and Disarmament Agency at [[US Department of State]] 1981 ==Affiliations== * Director of the Center on Chinese Strategy, [[Hudson Institute]], 1201 Pennsylvania Ave, Washington DC, 2014–present * Member of the Board of Directors, [[Freedom House]], Washington, DC, 2016–present * Member of the Advisory Council, Woodrow Wilson Center, Washington D.C.{{cite web|url=https://www.wilsoncenter.org/|title=Wilson Center|website=Wilson Center|accessdate=7 November 2018}} * [[National Geographic Society]], Member of Council of Advisors and Founding Co-chairman of the Explorers Society, 2012-2014 * Eagle Donor to [[Republican National Committee]], with reported donatation of over $100,000 since 2008{{cite web|url=https://www.opensecrets.org/donor-lookup/results?name=Michael+Pillsbury&page=2|title=Donor Lookup|website=Opensecrets.org|accessdate=7 November 2018}} * Member, [[Republican Governors Association]], Executive Roundtable, 2014–present * Member of [http://dcgop.com/advisory-council/ Washington DC Republican GOP Advisory Council], 2012–present * Author of number one National Bestseller, [http://thehundredyearmarathon.com/ The Hundred- year Marathon], also published in Korean, Japanese, Taiwan-Chinese and PRC-Chinese edition published by Chinese National Defense University, and published in Hindi and Mongolian; selected as "one of the 10 best books of the year" by the Christian Science Monitor; * Member of the Board of Directors French American Cultural Center, 1430 New York Ave, Washington, DC, 2015–present[http://frenchamericancultural.org/ French American Cultural Center]{{full|date=November 2018}} ==Published works== ===Books=== Author of two books on China, available at [[National Defense University]] Press: * {{cite book|year=2015|url=http://thehundredyearmarathon.com/|title=The Hundred-Year Marathon: China's Secret Strategy to Replace America as the Global Superpower|isbn=978-1-6277-9010-9|last1=Pillsbury|first1=Michael}} * {{cite book|year=2000|url=http://www.ndu.edu/inss/books/books%20-%202000/China%20Debates%20Future%20Sec%20Environ%20Jan%202000/pills2.htm|title=China Debates the Future Security Environment|isbn=978-1-4102-1856-8|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625191211/http://www.ndu.edu/inss/books/books%20-%202000/China%20Debates%20Future%20Sec%20Environ%20Jan%202000/pills2.htm|archivedate=2009-06-25|df=|last1=Pillsbury|first1=Michael}}
This book has been translated and published in China by the New China News Agency Press * {{cite book|year=1998|title=Chinese Views of Future Warfare|url=http://www.ndu.edu/inss/books/books%20-%201998/Chinese%20Views%20of%20Future%20Warfare%20-%20Sept%2098//chinacont.html|isbn=978-1-57906-016-9|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709073729/http://www.ndu.edu/inss/books/books%20-%201998/Chinese%20Views%20of%20Future%20Warfare%20-%20Sept%2098/chinacont.html|archivedate=2009-07-09|df=|last1=Pillsbury|first1=Michael}} (editor) ===Reports and articles=== ====US China Commission Congressional Reports==== * {{cite journal|url=http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2005/05_04_21_technological_progress.pdf |title=China's Progress in Technological Competitiveness – The Need for a New Assessment |year=2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507200349/http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2005/05_04_21_technological_progress.pdf |archivedate=2009-05-07 |df= }} * {{cite journal|url=http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2004/04_05_24_dr_pspeechintaipei_final1.php |title=The US Role in Taiwan's Defense Reforms |year=2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625002326/http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2004/04_05_24_dr_pspeechintaipei_final1.php |archivedate=2009-06-25 |df= }} * {{cite journal|url=http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2000_2003/pdfs/strat.pdf |title=China's Military Strategy Toward the U.S.: A View From Open Sources |year=2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114040628/http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2000_2003/pdfs/strat.pdf |archivedate=2006-11-14 |df= }} * {{cite journal|oclc=165065634|url=http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA476735|title=An Assessment of China's Anti-Satellite And Space Warfare Programs, Policies And Doctrines|date=January 19, 2007|publisher=Defense Technical Information Center}} * {{cite book|oclc=43387159|title=China's Assessment of the Future Security Environment|year=1998|publisher=Office of Net Assessment}} * {{cite book|oclc=53477900|title=Dangerous Chinese Misperceptions: The Implications for the Department of Defense|year=1996|publisher=Office of Net Assessment}} * {{cite book|oclc=6368991|title=Chinese Perceptions of the Soviet-American Military Balance|year=1980|publisher=Office of Net Assessment}} ====House and Senate testimonies==== * {{cite journal|url=http://commdocs.house.gov/committees/security/has173000.000/has173000_0f.htm|title=Testimony to House Armed Services Committee|date= June 21, 2000}} * {{cite journal|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/intell/library/congress/1997_hr/970918-pillsbury.htm|title=Testimony Before the United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|date=November 1997}} ====Journal articles==== * {{cite journal|jstor=1148172|title=Strategic Acupuncture|journal=Foreign Policy|issue=Winter 1980|pages=44–61|year=1980|last1=Pillsbury|first1=Michael|doi=10.2307/1148172}} * {{cite journal|jstor=1148126|title=US-China Military Ties?|journal=Foreign Policy|issue=Autumn 1975|pages=50–64|year=1975|last1=Pillsbury|first1=Michael|doi=10.2307/1148126}} * {{cite journal|jstor=1148458|title=A Japanese Card?|journal=Foreign Policy|issue=Winter 1978|pages=3–30|year=1978|last1=Pillsbury|first1=Michael|doi=10.2307/1148458}} * {{cite journal|doi=10.2307/2538627|jstor=2538627|title=Future Sino American Security Ties: The View from Tokyo, Moscow, and Peking|journal=International Security|issue=Spring 1977|pages=124–142|volume=1|year=1977|last1=Pillsbury|first1=Michael P}} ====RAND Corporation reports==== Some of these are available online:{{cite web|url=https://www.rand.org/pubs/authors/p/pillsbury_michael.html|title=Michael Pillsbury|website=Rand.org|accessdate=7 November 2018}} * {{cite book|title=Personal Ties and Factionalism in Peking|year=1975|oclc=1575577|publisher=RAND Corporation}} * {{cite book|title=Taiwan's fate: Two Chinas But Not Forever|year=1975|oclc=1575589|publisher=RAND Corporation}} * {{cite book|title=The Political Environment on Taiwan|year=1975|oclc=1462258|publisher=RAND Corporation}} * {{cite book|title=SALT on the Dragon: Chinese Views of the Soviet-American Strategic Balance|oclc=2218652|year=1975|publisher=RAND Corporation}} * {{cite book|title=Soviet Apprehensions about Sino-American Relations, 1971–74|year=1975|oclc=1549446|publisher=RAND Corporation}} * {{cite book|title=Statement to the Subcommittee on Future Foreign Policy Research and Development, Committee on International Relations, House of Representatives|oclc=2731888|year=1976|publisher=RAND Corporation}} * {{cite book|oclc= 2379124|title=Chinese Foreign Policy: Three New Studies|publisher=RAND Corporation|year=1975}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Michael Pillsbury's op-ed in ''The Hill'': [http://thehill.com/opinion/international/386286-trump-wins-the-first-round-in-us-china-trade-war Trump wins the first round in US-China trade war ], May 4, 2018 * ''New York Post'' Book Review: [https://nypost.com/2015/02/08/chinas-secret-plan-to-topple-the-us-as-the-worlds-superpower/ China's secret plan to topple the US as the world's superpower], February 8, 2015 * ''Wall Street Journal'': [https://www.wsj.com/video/opinion-journal-chinas-peaceful-rise-is-a-mirage/95633796-302B-4113-9621-783459CF4E1F.html Opinion Journal: China's 'Peaceful Rise' Is a Mirage], February 5, 2015 * Michael Pillsbury's interview on Fox News: [http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/10/13/china-tries-to-blame-us-for-hong-kong-protests/ President Xi Jinping I and the Hong Kong Crisis ], October 13, 2014 * Pillsbury's op-ed in the ''Wall Street Journal'': [https://online.wsj.com/articles/misunderstanding-china-1410972607 Misunderstanding China ], September 17, 2014 * {{cite journal|title=As polygraph screening flourishes, critics say oversight abandoned|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2012/12/06/176310/as-polygraph-screening-flourishes.html|last=Taylor|first=Marisa|agency=[[McClatchy Newspapers]]|accessdate=December 6, 2012}} * Pillsbury discusses the Chinese economy on Fox News: [http://video.foxnews.com/v/1587771837001/will-chinas-economy-continue-to-grow Will China's economy continue to grow?] * Pillsbury on PBSNewsHour: revision.text:
{{Infobox American Indian chief |name = Mushulatubbee |image = Mosholatubbee.jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = Mosholatubbee, painted by [[George Catlin]] |tribe = [[Choctaw]] |lead = 1815–1838 |birth_date = c. 1750–1770 |birth_place = [[Mississippi]] |death_date = c. 1838 |death_place = [[Arkansas]] |predecessor = Hoomastubbee |successor = David Folsom |native_name = |nicknames = |known_for = [[Tribal chief]] |death_cause = smallpox |resting_place = |rp_coordinates = |religion = [[Choctaw mythology|traditional Choctaw religion]] |party = |education = |spouse = two wives |partner = |children = |parents = [[Homastubbee]] |relations = |signature = |footnotes = }}
'''Mushulatubbee''' ([[Choctaw language|Choctaw]] ''{{lang|cho|AmoshuliTabi}}'', "Determined to Kill") (born c. 1750–1770, died c. 1838) was the chief of the [[Choctaw]] ''Okla Tannap'' ("Lower Towns"), one of the three major Choctaw divisions during the early 19th century. When the Principal Chief [[Greenwood LeFlore]] stayed in Mississippi at the time of [[Indian Removal Act|removal]], Mushulatubbee was elected as principal chief, leading the tribe to [[Indian Territory]].
In 1812 he had led his warriors to assist General [[Andrew Jackson]] in the war against the Creek [[Red Sticks]], known as the [[Creek Wars]].
In December 1824 Mushulatubbee was one of three principal chiefs leading a Choctaw delegation to Washington to seek help against encroaching European-American settlers. [[Pushmataha]] and [[Apuckshunubbee]] were the other chiefs; Apuckshunubbee, age 80, died before they reached Washington, and Pushmataha died of illness in the capital soon after their meeting with the government.
On 26 September 1830, together with the Principal Chief Greenwood LeFlore and others, Mushulatubbee signed the [[Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek]], which ceded to the US government most of the remaining Choctaw territory in [[Mississippi]] and [[Alabama]] in exchange for territory in [[Indian Territory]]. Other spellings for his name include: ''Mosholetvbbi'', ''AmoshuliTvbi'', ''Musholatubbee'', ''Moshaleh Tubbee'', and ''Mushulatubba''.
==Creek Wars== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2012}} The great Shawnee leader [[Tecumseh]] visited Mushulatubbee in 1811 when he came south to get support for his Great Confederacy, in an effort to push out the European Americans. Today it is known as [[Tecumseh's Confederacy]]. Tecumseh met Moshulatubbee at his village Mashulaville (located in present-day [[Noxubee County, Mississippi]]). He was chief of ''Okla Tannap'' (Lower Towns), the southern division of the three major geographic and [[clan]] Choctaw areas of settlement. Other major divisions were in the northeast, including part of Alabama; and the west, near Vicksburg. Mushulatubbee had sympathy for Tecumseh and his cause, but decided he was too old to do anything for the confederacy, so remained neutral.
In addition to fighting with Jackson and his forces against the Creek, Mushulatubbee led 52 Choctaw warriors in the [[Battle of New Orleans]] in 1814. They fought in the swamps and cypress trees, picking off many British pickets and demoralizing them. They kept shooting down the Red Coats, as they were fighting for their homeland. When the [[Battle of New Orleans]] was over, Moshulatubbee and his 52 warriors returned home. They left the service on January 27, 1815, from Fort Stoddard.
==Land cessions== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2012}} Under continuing pressure from European-American settlers and the United States government, Mushulatubbee signed the [[Treaty of the Choctaw Trading House]] on 24 October 1816, and the [[Treaty Ground]] on 18 October 1820 to cede land. The US failed to prevent settlers from continuing to encroach on Choctaw territory.
==Journey to Washington== In 1824, [[Pushmataha]], Mushulatubee, and [[Apuckshunubbee]], the three chiefs of the Choctaw regional divisions, became concerned about the encroaching settlement of European Americans and the unwillingness of local authorities to respect Indian land titles. They still hoped to offset the government's push for removal west of the Mississippi River and resolved to take their case to the Federal government in [[Washington, D.C.]] Pushmataha led the delegation; they sought either expulsion of white settlers from deeded lands in [[Arkansas]], or compensation in land and cash for such lands.<ref name=mhs> {{cite web | url = http://mshistory.k12.ms.us/features/feature18/pushmataha.html | title = Pushmataha: Choctaw Warrior, Diplomat, and Chief | accessdate = 2006-11-29 | last = O'Brien | first = Greg | year = 2004 | work = Mississippi History NOW | publisher = Mississippi Historical Society |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060925005101/http://mshistory.k12.ms.us/features/feature18/pushmataha.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2006-09-25}}</ref> The group also consisted of Talking Warrior, Red Fort, ''Nittahkachee'', Col. [[Robert Cole (Choctaw)|Robert Cole]] and [[David Folsom (Choctaw)|David Folsom]], both ([[mixed-race]]) Choctaw; Captain Daniel McCurtain; and Major John Pitchlynn, the U.S. Interpreter.<ref name=choctaw_nation_earl_white> {{cite web|url=http://www.choctawnation.com/History/index.cfm?fuseaction=HArticle&HArticleID=1 |title=Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma |accessdate=2008-02-05 |last=White |first=Earl |coauthors= |date= |work= |publisher=Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913031945/http://www.choctawnation.com/History/index.cfm?fuseaction=HArticle&HArticleID=1 |archivedate=September 13, 2009 }} </ref>
They planned to travel the [[Natchez Trace]] to Nashville, then to [[Lexington, Kentucky]]; onward to [[Maysville, Kentucky]]; across the [[Ohio River]] (called the ''Spaylaywitheepi'' by the Shawnee) northward to [[Chillicothe, Ohio]] (former principal town of the Shawnee); then finally east over the "National Highway" to Washington City. <ref name=choctaw_nation_earl_white />
While in Washington, the chief also met with the [[Marquis de Lafayette]], who was visiting [[Washington, D.C.]] for the last time. He hailed him as a fellow aged warrior who, though foreign, rose to high renown in the American cause.
{{quote|You are one of our fathers that fought in the War with Gen. [[George Washington]]. We take you here by the hand as a friend and a father. We have always walked in the white paths of peace; and in those paths we have traveled to visit you. We offer you pure hands, which have never been stained with the blood of Americans.-- We live in the south, where the sun shines hot upon us. We have been neighbors to the [[France|French]], neighbors to the [[Spaniards]], and neighbors to the [[England|English]]: but now our only neighbors are the Americans, in the midst of whom we live as friends and brothers.|Mushulatubba, ''The Essex Register '', 2 December 1824.<ref name="marquis_speech"> {{cite news | title = Interview of Lafayette and the Indian Chiefs at Washington | publisher = The Essex Register | date = 2 December 1824 }}</ref> }}
==Candidate for U.S. Congress== In 1830 Mushulatubbee announced his candidacy for office in Mississippi in the ''Port Gibson Correspondent'', as reported by the ''Christian Mirror and N.H. Observer'' (15 July 1830).<ref name="us_congress"> {{cite news | title = An Indian Candidate for Congress | publisher = Christian Mirror and N.H. Observer, Shirley, Hyde & Co. | date = 15 July 1830 }}</ref>
{{quote|To the voters of Mississippi. Fellow Citizens:-I have fought for you, I have been by your own act, made a citizen of your state; ... According to your laws I am an American citizen, ... I have always battled on the side of this republic ... I have been told by my white brethren, that the pen of history is impartial, and that in after years, our forlorn kindred will have justice and 'mercy too'.|Mushulatubba, ''Christian Mirror and N.H. Observer'', July 1830.<ref name="us_congress"/> }}
The US government forced the Choctaw to remove to [[Indian Territory]] west of the Mississippi River. Mushulatubbee was the chief of his division during the removal and for a time after their resettlement in what became [[Oklahoma]]. The government had encouraged the Choctaw to resettle in their former clan divisions. Relocation soon led to changes in the society in which those clan divisions became less important.
In 1838 Mushulatubbee died of [[smallpox]] in present-day [[Arkansas]] and was buried near [[Cameron, Oklahoma]] in [[Le Flore County, Oklahoma]].
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Apuckshunubbee]] *[[Pushmataha]] *[[Greenwood LeFlore]] *[[George W. Harkins]] *[[Peter Pitchlynn]] *[[Phillip Martin]] *[[List of Choctaw chiefs]] *[[List of Choctaw treaties]] {{div col end}}
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Lafarge, Oliver. ''A Pictorial History of the American Indian'', Crown Publishers, Inc., 1956: 41.
==External links== *[https://archive.is/20070504024523/http://www.choctawnation.com/History/index.cfm?fuseaction=HArticle&HArticleID=2 "History"], Choctaw Nation Official Website *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070310153534/http://mshistory.k12.ms.us/features/feature14/choctaw_removal.html "Choctaw Removal: Assessment of Mushulatubbee's role"], Mississippi History
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mushulatubbee}} [[Category:18th-century births]] [[Category:1830s deaths]] [[Category:Native American leaders]] [[Category:Choctaw people]]

{{Islam}}
'''Muslim ibn Aqil Al-Hashimi''' ([[Arabic]]: مسلم بن عقيل الهاشمي) was the son of [[Aqeel ibn Abi Talib]] and a member of the clan of [[Bani Hashim]], thus, he is a cousin of [[Husayn ibn Ali]]. The people of Kufa called upon Husayn to overthrow the [[Umayyad dynasty]] who was on his way to Mecca for the [[Hajj]] pilgrimage. He wanted to confirm the loyalty of the people of Kufa, so he sent his cousin and his ambassador, Muslim ibn Aqeel, a famous warrior, to Kufa to observe the situation. He sent a letter to Husayn confirming their loyalty, before knowing that the 30,000 followers that he gained would all betray him. He was executed by the newly installed governor, [[Ubayd Allah ibn Ziyad]], on the 20th of Rabi Ul Awal, 60 AH,<ref>http://www.hujjat.org/index.php?option=com_content&id=142:hadhrat-muslim-ibn-aqeel-a&catid=28&Itemid=100013</ref> and is buried at the back of [[Great Mosque of Kufa]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jafariyanews.com/2k3_news/apr/27_kufa.htm |title=Hundreds of thousands’ Friday assemblage in Masjid-e-Uzma Kufa |accessdate=20 November 2008 |work=Jafariyanews.com }}</ref>
==Journey to Kufa==
=== Letters from Kufa===
Husayn ibn Ali received thousands of letters from people of [[Kufa]] stating that they were rejecting their governor and asking him to come and serve as their Imam. One letter in particular contained these words: ''“We invite you to come to Kufa as we have no Imam to guide us. Through you Allah will unite us on the path of truth.”'' A few days later, the people of Kufa sent an emissary, a special messenger, to Husayn ibn Ali to persuade him to go to Kufa. There followed hundreds of other letters and many special emissaries from the people of Kufa to Husayn ibn Ali.
Receiving so many petitions and messages from Kufa, Husayn ibn Ali decided to send Muslim ibn Aqeel, who was a famous warrior, as his emissary to Kufa to study the situation there and report to Husayn ibn Ali.<ref>[[Barnaby Rogerson|Rogerson, Barnaby]]. '''The Heirs of Muhammad'''. Woodstock, NY: The Overlook Press, 2006.</ref>
===Muslim's Assignment===
He wrote a letter to the people of Kufa and gave it to Muslim ibn Aqeel. In this letter Husayn ibn Ali said, ''“I am sending my cousin and one of the most trusted ones from my family, Muslim ibn Aqeel, to report to me about your affairs. If his report agrees with what you have written I will soon be with you. You must be clear of the fact that the Imam is the only one who follows the book of Allah, and serves Allah in all matters and affairs with justice, honesty and truth.”''<ref name=Jafri>Jafri, Syed Husian Mohammad. '''The Origins and Early Development of Shi'a Islam'''. Oxford: Orxford UP, 2000.</ref>
Husayn ibn Ali also told Ibn Aqeel: ''“Muslim, the whole world knows that you are one of the bravest warriors. It is just possible that seeing you in Kufa some people may think that our intention is to fight Yazid. Take your two sons Muhammad and Ibrahim with you. When they see you with such young children, they will know that our intentions are peaceful.”''
According to reports, Muslim ibn Aqeel’s sons were so young, that they could not even tie up the buttons of their shirts.
Husayn sent three people with Muslim: Qays Ibn Mash'ar, 'Imarah Ibn 'Abdullah al-Saluli, and 'Abdul Rahman Ibn 'Abdullah al-Azd, in addition to the messenger from Kufa.<ref name=Islam>Kitab al-Irshad. Excerpts from al-Islam.org</ref>
===Traveling to Kufa=== This group set off from [[Mecca]] on the 15th of Ramadan. His first destination was [[Medina]], where he left his family and hired two people to guide him on his way. The guides, however, lost their way in the desert and were too weak from lack of water to continue on. But in their weakened physical state, they managed to show Muslim the right direction before they both died of thirst.
==In Kufa==
=== The Kufan's Pledge of Allegiance=== Muslim arrived in Kufa on 5 Shawwal 60 AH/ 9 July 680. He went first to the house of al-Mukhtar ibn Abu 'Ubayd al-Thaqafi, who was highly liked by his people and who later became the person who ordered the murder of Ibn Ziyad.<ref name=Julius>Wellhausen, Julius. '''The Religio-Political Factions in Early Islam.''' New York: U of Hull, 1975.</ref>
More than 18,000-30,000 people appeared before Muslim ibn Aqeel and enthusiastically pledged their allegiance to Husayn ibn Ali as their Imam and pledged to support Husayn even with their lives.<ref name=Tabari>Tabari. Excerpts from Al-Islam.org.</ref> Muslim ibn Aqeel, encouraged by this response, reported to Husayn ibn Ali by letter that he should proceed to Kufa.<ref name=Jafri />
The governor of Kufa, al-Nu'man Ibn Bashir, was told of Muslim's arrival, but refused to attack him. Bashir was a mild man and did not want to harm the members of the family of the Prophet, so he did nothing to stop Muslim.<ref name=Ayoub>Ayoub, Mahmoud. '''Redeptive Suffering in Islam'''. London: U of Toronto, 1978.</ref> Many of the supporters of Yazid saw this lack of action as a sign of weakness and encouraged the caliph to replace Bashir with a stronger man. Yazid then deposed Bashir and replaced him with Ubayd Allah ibn Ziyad. Ibn Ziyad was a resourceful and often cruel politician who spared nothing in order to attain political ends. His strong and ruthless character was exactly what the caliph was looking for in order to gain control in Kufa.<ref name=Ayoub/> Yazid wrote to him, ''"Go to Kufa, capture Muslim ibn 'Aqil and see what is appropriate to imprison him, send him to exile or kill him."'' <ref name=Brill>Kohlberg, E. "Muslim B. Akil B. Ali Talib" '''The Encyclopedia of Islam'''. 2nd ed. Online.</ref>
===Governor's Warning=== The morning of his arrival in Kufa, Ibn Ziyad gathered the people at the grand mosque. There he delivered a speech warning them against mutiny and promised them generous rewards for conforming. He said, ''"Anyone found to be sheltering one of those who scheme against the authority of the commander of the faithful and who does not hand him over will be crucified on the door of his own house".'' <ref name=Islam/>
===Searching for Muslim=== During this time, Ibn Ziyad was working diligently to discover the hiding place of Muslim. He knew that the people of Kufa were meeting secretly, but he was not able to figure out the location. Ibn Ziyad decided that the best way to find Muslim would be to infiltrate his inner circle. He called upon his servant, Ma'qil, to meet him. He gave Ma'qil three thousand dirhams and ordered him to meet with the Shi'as. He was to tell them that he was a Syrian slave who has just arrived in the country and wanted to hand deliver a donation to Muslim. Ma'qil entered the grand mosque and was introduced to Muslim. Ma'qil then delivered the money and swore allegiance to him. This servant continued to meet with Muslim in the coming days. No secrets were kept from him, so he kept gathering information, which he then reported back to Ibn Ziyad in the evenings.<ref name=Brill/>
===Hani's Arrest=== With the information from Ma'qil, Ibn Ziyad was able to figure out that Muslim was staying at the house of Hani. The governor gathered some of the friends of Hani and asked why he had not visited in quite a while. They made excuses for him, saying that he had been sick and other similar things. Hani was then summoned by the governor who accused him of harboring Muslim in his house.<ref name=Islam/> Hani denied this claim and things got heated. Ibn Ziyad then called in Ma'qil and had him corroborate the story that Ibn Ziyad was trying to paint. At this point, Hani was arrested, beaten in the face with an iron-tipped cane, and thrown into prison and was later executed with Muslim ibn Aqeel.
Muslim reported to Husayn through Abis ibn Shabib that most of the people in Kufa were ready to receive him as their Imam and advised that Husayn should proceed to Kufa (Tareekh-e-Tabri, Vol.6, Page211). Amongst the people of Kufa there were many spies employed by Yazid to report to him directly. When Yazid heard from them of the invitations to Hussain and the arrival in Kufa of Muslim he was filled with fury. He sent a message to his Governor in Basrah, Ubaydullah ibn Ziyad, to go to Kufa and take over the position of Nu'amaan ibne Basheer. Ibn Ziyad was also told to arrest Muslim and murder him and do all that was necessary to suppress the Shiahs in Kufa.
Ibn Ziyad was a shrewd man. He kept his journey from Basra to Kufa a secret and just before entering Kufa he covered his face with a black scarf so that he could not be recognized. He had a few horsemen in front of him and a few behind him as he entered Kufa. The people of Kufa had been waiting for the arrival of Imam Hussain anxiously and they presumed that the Imam had arrived. Soon people started gathering around him and singing welcoming songs. Ibn Ziyad kept observing the people and memorizing faces as the crowd grew and soon it was difficult for his convoy to proceed swiftly. One of his guards, Muslim bin Amr Bahili, shouted "Clear the way, this is the Amir Ubaidullah ibn Ziyad". Hearing this, people started running away quickly and when Ibn Ziyad reached the Dar-al-Amara only a handful people had been left. Ibn Ziyad arrived in Kufa on the evening of 2nd Dhul-Hajj. On the following day he went to the mosque and addressed the people of Kufa. He first announced his appointment as Yazid's governor. He then threatened any one who was engaged in any activity against the government with immediate death, and ordered them to surrender Muslim to him.
Ibn Ziyad sealed Kufa in such a way that no one could go in or out of the city without the governor's permission.
==Death==
Since several people knew that he was staying with Mukhtar Thaqafi, Muslim decided to move from there as a measure of precaution and protection. At the invitation of Hani ibn Urwah, another leading member of the Shia community, he moved to Hani's house. This was done secretly and except for a few people no one knew where Muslim was. Through a spy, Maaqal, who pretended to be a Shia, Ibn Ziyad found out where Muslim was. Since ibn Ziyad had prior relations with Hani, he called him by trick to his palace and got him arrested and thrown into prison. Muslim got the news of Hani's arrest and not wishing to further endanger the lives of his friends, Muslim and his two sons left Hani's house. He left the children with Shurayb, a judge, and went into the desert to try to get back to Husayn to warn him not to go to Kufa. This was the 7th of Dhul-Hajj. That whole day and the following day Muslim tried to get out of the city. He found all the exits sealed and guarded by Ibn Ziyad's soldiers.
=== Muslim at the House of Tuwaa === On the 7th, late in the evening, tired, hungry and exhausted, [[Muslim]] knocked on the door of a house on the outskirts of the city. A lady named 'Tuwaa" opened the door. Muslim requested for a little water to quench his thirst. The lady gave him water. When she learnt who he was, she invited him in and offered him shelter for the night. She gave Muslim food and water and took him to a room where he spent the night.
Late that night Tuwaa's son came home. When he learned that the man Ibn Ziyad was looking for was in his mother's house, he felt that he would be rewarded by the governor if he got Muslim arrested. Unknown to his mother he slipped out in the darkness of the night and gave the information to a captain in Ibn Ziyad's army. Early the next morning, five hundred soldiers under the leadership of Mohammad bin Ashas surrounded the house of Tuwaa and demanded Muslim's surrender. Muslim came out holding his sword. Three times he drove the enemy away and killed 150 men. Twice Ibn Ziyad had to send in reinforcements.
While Muslim was fighting, some soldiers went up the rooftops and began throwing stones and lighted torches at him. Others dug a trench in the path of Muslim and covered it with grass. Ibn Ziyad told his commanders to trick Muslim otherwise it would not be possible to capture him. Although badly wounded and totally exhausted, Muslim kept on fighting. As a trick, soldiers of Ibn Ziyad offered peace and protection to Muslim but he rejected the offer. He was deeply wounded in this tough fight and finally fell into the trench. He was pounced upon, chained and dragged to the court of Ibn Ziyad.
===Execution=== Historians narrate that Muslim was badly wounded when he entered the court of Ibn Ziyad. His teeth were broken and blood was flowing from all over. Still he entered the court like a 'Lion'. Someone in the court told him to pay respect to Ibn Ziyad because he is the "Amir" (Ruler). Muslim refused and replied that his [[Amir]] was only Husayn.
Ibn Ziyad told Muslim that he would be killed and asked him if he had any last wishes. Muslim replied saying, "I owe a debt which should be discharged by selling off my sword and armour. Secondly I want my body to be given a proper burial. Thirdly I want a message sent to Hussain advising him not to come to Kufa." Ibn Ziyad agreed to the first request but refused to do anything about the second and third requests. He then ordered Muslim to be taken to the roof of the palace to be executed and his body thrown to the ground.
Muslim was calm and composed as he was dragged up the steps. He was reciting "Allahu Akber" until the last moment. Then there was an absolute silence followed by a thud as the head of Muslim was chopped and his body fell to the ground. This was on the 9th of Dhul-Hujja. Immediately after Muslim was killed, Hani ibn Urwah as well was dragged to the roof top and executed.
Ibn Ziyad ordered [[Muqair Ibn Obran-e-Ahmari]] to take him to the palace's roof.<ref name= Julius/> They went to the top of the fortress, Muslim was decapitated in front of the people, his head was thrown down first and then followed by his body. Hani was also executed. They were executed in this way in order to intimidate the populace.<ref name=Ayoub/> Ibn Ziyad ordered that the bodies of these two men be dragged by their feet through the streets and marketplaces in Kufa. Muslim's body was then crucified upside down and the heads of Muslim and Hani were sent to Yazid to be displayed on the streets of Damascus.<ref name=Brill/>
Muslim bin Aqeel’s two sons, Mohammad and Ibrahim, were also killed in Kufa.
===Muslim is made a [[Shaheed]]===
Muslim called on the people of Kufa for assistance and narrations say that approximately 40,000 people accompanied him to the government building. By then, Ibn Ziyad had placed the leaders of Kufa on the roof top of the building and threatened to kill them if they did not leave Muslim bin Aqeel.
Within a short while, not one person from the 40,000 was with Muslim.
Muslim was later taken by the soldiers of Ibn Ziyaad and was martyred. Later, the two sons of Muslim were also martyred. These were two young children who accompanied their father, thinking that they were journeying to a place that was filled with true followers of the Ahle Bait.
===Husayn departs for Kufa===
On receiving the letter of Muslim, Hussain departed from Makkah and left for Kufa. When this group of the Ahlul Bayt left Makkah, every person and every child stood watching them with sadness as they left.
Their eyes filled with tears and their hearts heavy with sadness. On his way, he received news of the death of Muslim and his children. Hussain was also informed of the betrayal of the people of Kufa. He was very sad when he heard this news and read In'na lil'laahi Wa in'na ilaihi Raaji'oon. He then comforted the family members and gave them hope.
When the Ahlul Bayt reached a place called Thaa'lba, Hussain rested for a while. He awoke with tears in his eyes. His beloved sister, Zainab asked the reason for this, and he said, "I dreamt of our grandfather, Rasulullah Sallallahu Alaihi Wasallam. The Prophet Sallallahu Alaihi Wasallam was crying and he said "O Hussain! You are soon to come and meet with me."
On hearing this, Ali Akbar the son of Hussain said, " O my dear father! Are we not on Haq (truth)?" Hussain replied, "verily we are on Haq and Haq is with us." Then Ali Akbar said, "why then should we fear death, O my father? We all must pass from this world one day. I am seeing the gardens of Shahaadat and a mansion better than that of the world and bounties even greater than that of this world are before us."
==Legacy== While Muslim was not killed at [[Karbala]], he is counted as one of the martyrs of the battle.<ref name=Ayoub/><ref>Dorraj, Manochehr. "Symbolic nd Utilitarian Political Value of a Tradition: Martyrdom in the Iranian Political Culture" '''The Review of Politics'''. Summer 1997:511. JSTOR.</ref>
The Shi'ite recommend visiting his grave in Kufa and there are certain prayers that are to be recited there.<ref name=Islam/>
On the other hand, there is the [[mausoleum]] of [[Ruqayyah bint Ali]] (Wife of Muslim ibn Aqeel) located in [[Lahore]], [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]].<sup>[[Bibi Pak Daman#cite note-ref93gifel-1|[1]]]</sup> Legend has it that it holds the graves of six ladies (one is Ruqqayah herself and others are Muslim's sisters) from [[Muhammad]]'s household ([[Ahl Al-Bayt]]).
Today, Muslim ibn Aqeel's descendants go by the surname "Uqaili" and are found in [[Pakistan]], [[Iran]], and [[Iraq]].
==See also== * [[Aqeel ibn Abu Talib]] * [[Bibi Pak Daman|Ruqayyah bint Ali]] * [[Muhammad ibn Muslim and Ibraheem ibn Muslim]] * [[Hani ibn Urwa]] * [[Ahl ul-Bayt]]

{{Infobox person | name = Oyub Titiev | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Oyub Salmanovich Titiev | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1957|8|24|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Lebedinovka]], Kyrgyz SSR, Soviet Union | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (DEATH date then BIRTH date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Activist, head of Memorial in Grozny, Chechnya | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Oyub Salmanovich Titiev''' ({{lang-ru|Оюб Салманович Титиев}}; born 24 August 1957, [[Lebedinovka]], Kyrgyz SSR, Soviet Union) is a Russian human rights activist and the head of [[Memorial_(society)|Memorial's]] [[Grozny|Grozny, Chechnya]] office. In 2018 he was arrested on politically-motivated charges, sparking an international campaign by human rights groups calling for his release. On 8 October 2018, Oyub Titiev was awarded the Václav Havel Human Rights Prize, which honours "outstanding" defence of human rights in Europe and beyond.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://website-pace.net/web/apce/vaclav-havel-human-rights-prize|title=Václav Havel Human Rights Prize|website=website-pace.net|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-09}}</ref> == Biography == Oyub Titiev’s ancestors were among the first settlers of the village Kurchaloi, Chechnya. However, as a result of the [[Deportation_of_the_Chechens_and_Ingush|deportation of Chechens in March 1944]] he was born in the village of Lebedinovka in the Kyrgyz SSR. He later returned to Kurchaloi, Chechnya. Active in wrestling and weightlifting, Titiev became a physical education teacher and created a local children's sports club, which has produced a number of professional athletes.
Since 2000, he has worked for [https://www.memo.ru/en-us/ Memorial] and for the [https://refugee.ru/en/ Civic Assistance Committee], documenting human rights abuses in Chechnya and overseeing humanitarian projects such as assisting schools in Chechnya’s mountain regions or defending Muslims from discrimination in the criminal justice system. After the assassination of [[Natalya Estemirova]] in 1999, he became the head of Memorial in Chechnya.
== Arrest, detention and criminal case == On 9 January 2018 Oyub Titiev left Kurchaloi, traveling towards Mairtup, Chechnya, where he was supposed to meet a friend at 9:00 am.<ref>{{cite web |title=Human Rights Centre Memorial |url=https://memohrc.org/en/news_old/head-memorials-office-grozny-chechnya-detained |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref> According to the official version, his Lada Kalina was stopped to verify his documents. Upon inspecting the car, the police officers found “a polymer bag with a substance of plant origin with the specific smell of marijuana, weighing approximately 180 grams.” Titiev was then detained and taken to the Kurchaloevsky police station for medical examination, while the packet with the substance was sent for expert analysis<ref>{{cite web |title=Rights Defender Arbitrarily Arrested in Chechnya |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/01/11/russia-rights-defender-arbitrarily-arrested-chechnya |website=Human Rights Watch}}</ref>. That same day, Memorial reported his detention.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chechnya moves to silence a courageous critic |url=https://www.economist.com/europe/2018/01/17/chechnya-moves-to-silence-oyub-titiev-a-courageous-critic |website=The Economist |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref><ref><{{cite web |title=Head of Grozny HRC Memorial was arrested |url=https://www.memo.ru/en-us/memorial/departments/intermemorial/news/110 |website=Memorial |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>
On 11 January 2018, the Shalinsk city court arrested Titiev until March 9 on request of the investigator<ref>{{cite web |title=Oyub Titiev detained and facing criminal investigation |url=https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/oyub-titiev-detained-and-facing-criminal-investigation |website=Frontline Defenders |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>. The human rights activist was accused of breaking Part 2 Article 228 of the Criminal Code (the illegal acquisition, storage, and transportation of drugs)<ref>{{cite web |title=Ongoing judicial harassment and arbitrary detention of Mr. Oyub Titiev |url=https://www.fidh.org/en/issues/human-rights-defenders/russian-federation-ongoing-judicial-harassment-and-arbitrary |website=Worldwide Movement for Human Rights |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>. Titiev denied guilt and in a statement sent to the Investigatory Committee of the Chechen Republic accused the police officers of planting the illegal drugs under his passenger’s seat while inspecting his car<ref>{{cite web |title=Pre-trial detention of Oyub Titiev confirmed in appeal hearing amid fears for his safety in detention |url=https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/oyub-titiev-detained-and-facing-criminal-investigation |website=Frontline Defenders |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>. On 12 January, his defense appealed the two-month arrest.
Memorial representative Aleksandr Cherkasov said that Titiev’s arrest was related to his professional work which was “met with disapproval from Chechen authorities.” The representative of the [[Presidential Council for Civil Society and Human Rights]], Mikhail Fedotov, said that the council had already appealed to the Ministry of Internal Affairs on January 10th to verify Titiev’s detention and investigate the situation.
On 24 January, Aleksandr Cherkasov appealed to the Russian and international community on behalf of Memorial, urging them to closely monitor Titiev’s case as they had with criminal proceedings against historian and head of the Karelian branch of Memorial, [[Yury A. Dmitriev]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Address of the international Memorial to the Russian and international community (Russian) |url=https://echo.msk.ru/blog/shalommani/2135114-echo/ |website=Echo Moscow |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>. On January 28th, [[Ksenia Sobchak]], then a candidate in the [[Russian presidential election, 2018|March 2018 Russian Presidential Elections]], held a one-night-long picket in Grozny in “memory of journalists who died for a free country” with a poster reading “Freedom for Oyub Titiev.”<ref>{{cite web |title=Sobchak complained to police about provocateurs in Grozny |url=http://www.eng.kavkaz-uzel.eu/articles/42205/ |website=Caucasian Knot |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>
On 1 February the [http://eng.ombudsmanrf.org/ High Commissioner for Human Rights in Russia], [[Tatyana Moskalkova]] called for the investigation of the Titiev case to be passed on to the federal level. A similar opinion was expressed by the representative of the [[Presidential Council for Civil Society and Human Rights]], Mikhail Fedotov.<ref>{{cite web |title=The head of the HRC called the reasons for the transfer of Titiev's case |url=https://ria.ru/society/20180203/1513923046.html |website=RIA |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>
On 6 March the Staropromyslov district court extended Titiev’s arrest until 9 May, while rejecting the ''poruchitelstvo'' (personal vouches, Russian: поручительство) he received from presidential candidates Grigory Yavlinsky and Kesnia Sobchak<ref>{{cite web |title=Human rights defender Oyub Titiev’s detention extended for two months |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2018/03/russia-human-rights-defender-oyub-titievs-detention-extended-for-two-months/ |website=Amnesty International |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>.
On 4 May, while considering an appeal to the ruling of the Staropromyslov district court, human rights activist Svetlana Gannushkina and test pilot and Hero of Russia Sergey Nefedov also offered a ''poruchitelstvo'' for Titiev, which the court also rejected<ref>{{cite web |title=Court leaves Chechen rights defender Oyub Titiev under arrest |url=http://www.eng.kavkaz-uzel.eu/articles/43098/ |website=Caucasian Knot |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>.
A number of leading international human rights organizations, including [[Human Rights Watch]], [[Amnesty International]], [[Front Line Defenders]], [[FIDH]], the [[World Organization Against Torture]]) released a joint statement on 11 January, defending Titiev and Memorial’s activities in the Caucuses<ref>{{cite web |title=Rights Defender Arbitrarily Arrested in Chechnya |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/01/11/russia-rights-defender-arbitrarily-arrested-chechnya |website=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>. On 8 February, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on Oyub Titiev’s case calling for the "immediate release of the Director of the Memorial Human Rights Centre in the Chechen Republic, Mr Oyub Titiev"<ref>{{cite web |title=European Parliament resolution of 8 February on Russia, the case of Oyub Titiev and the Human Rights Centre Memorial |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?type=TA&language=EN&reference=P8-TA-2018-0034 |website=European Parliament |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>. Memorial has included Titiev in their list of political prisoners.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chechen human rights defender Oyub Titiev is a political prisoner, Memorial says |url=https://memohrc.org/en/news_old/chechen-human-rights-defender-oyub-titiev-political-prisoner-memorial-says |website=Human Rights Centre Memorial |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>
== References == <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Titiev, Oyub Salmanovich}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian human rights activists]] [[Category:Chechen human rights activists]] [[Category:Chechen people]] [[Category:Russian Muslims]]

revision.text:
'''Patricia Bean McConnell''' (born November 16, 1948) is an Adjunct Professor of [[Zoology]] at the [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]], and expert in animal behavior. She has written several books, including ''The Other End of the Leash'' and ''For the Love of a Dog,'' and produced a number of pet training DVDs.<ref>[http://zoology.wisc.edu/faculty/McConnell/McConnell.html McConnell, Patricia B.] University of Wisconsin-Madison</ref> In both her academic and popular writing she has focused on issues of [[interspecies communication]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Aline Mckenzie |coauthors= |title=Man's best friend is misunderstood |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2002&dat=20020721&id=fhovAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iNsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3497,4751257 |quote= |pages=C2 |work=Beaver County Times |agency=Knight Ridder |date=July 21, 2002 |accessdate=2015-02-16 }}</ref> She also runs her own publishing company, McConnell Publishing.
From 1994 to 2008, McConnell was the co-host of the weekly one-hour radio show ''Calling All Pets'' produced by [[Wisconsin Public Radio]], during which she dispensed advice about behavior problems and information about animal behavior research.<ref>[http://www.wpr.org/programs/calling-all-pets Calling All Pets], Wisconsin Public Radio</ref>
She retired from the University of Wisconsin-Madison in May 2015.
==Early life and education== McConnell was born in [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. One of her sisters is the poet [[Wendy Barker|Wendy Bean Barker]].
McConnell is a trained ethologist and Certified Applied Animal Behaviorist (CAAB), and received her PhD in Zoology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison in 1988. Her doctoral dissertation, "Acoustic structure and receiver response in mammalian signal systems", won the Warder Clyde Allee Competition.<ref>[http://www.animalbehaviorsociety.org/web/awards-allee.php Warder Clyde Allee Competition]</ref>
==Selected bibliography== *{{cite journal | author =Patricia B. McConnell | author2 =Jeffrey R. Baylis |date=December 1985 | title =Interspecific Communication in Cooperative Herding: Acoustic and Visual Signals from Human Shepherds and Herding Dogs | journal = Zeitschrift für Tierpsychologie| volume =67 | issue =1-4 | pages =302–328 | publisher = | location = | issn = | pmid = | doi =10.1111/j.1439-0310.1985.tb01396.x | bibcode = | oclc = | id = | url =http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1439-0310.1985.tb01396.x/abstract | language = | format = | accessdate = | laysummary = | laysource = | laydate = | quote = |authormask=1}} *{{cite book|last1=McConnell|first1=Patricia B.|title=The other end of the leash : why we do what we do around dogs|date=2003|publisher=Ballantine Books|location=New York|isbn=978-0345446787 |authormask=1}} (Published in 12 languages) *{{cite book|last1=McConnell|first1=Patricia B.|title=For the love of a dog : understanding emotion in you and your best friend|date=2007|publisher=Ballantine Books|location=New York|isbn=978-0345477156 |authormask=1}} ([[Audie Awards|Audie Award]], as the Best Audio Book of 2007)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://patriciamcconnell.com/ Author's website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070210032135/http://www.wpr.org/pets/ ''Calling All Pets'' website]
