{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox soap character | name = Victoria Lord | series = One Life to Live | portrayer = {{unbulleted list|[[Gillian Spencer]] (1968–70)|[[Joanne Dorian]] (1970–71)|[[Erika Slezak]] (1971–2013)}} | first = {{Start date|1968|7|15}} | last= {{End date|2013|8|19}} | years = 1968–2013 | creator= [[Agnes Nixon]] | introducer = {{unbulleted list|Doris Quinlan|[[Jennifer Pepperman]] (2013)}} | classification = [[List of One Life to Live cast members#Main cast|Final, regular]] | image1 = VictoriaLordOLTL.png | caption1 = Erika Slezak as Victoria Lord | image2 = | caption2 = Joanne Dorian as Victoria Lord | image3 = | caption3 = Gillian Spencer as Victoria Lord | books = ''Patrick's Notebook'' | alias = Niki Smith, Tommy, Jean Randolph, Princess, Tori Lord, Victor Lord ([[dissociative identity disorder|alternate personalities]]) | occupation = {{Plain list | * [[Media proprietor|Publishing magnate]] * [[Socialite]] * [[Businessperson|Businesswoman]] * [[Board of directors|Hospital board member]] * [[Waitress]] (2008) * [[Chancellor (education)|University president]] (2003–04) * [[Mayor]] (1990) }} | residence = [[Llanfair (One Life to Live)|Llanfair]]
1177 Regency Drive
[[Llanview, Pennsylvania]] 19100 | family = [[Lord family|Lord]] | parents = {{ubl|[[Victor Lord]]|[[Eugenia Randolph Lord]]}} | stepmother = [[Dorian Lord]] (1975–83) |halfbrothers= [[Tony Lord (One Life to Live)|Tony Lord]]
[[Todd Manning]]
[[Victor Lord, Jr.]] |sisters=[[Meredith Lord]] |halfsisters=[[Tina Lord]] | spouse = {{unbulleted list|[[Roger Gordon (One Life to Live)|Roger Gordon]] (annulled)|[[Joe Riley (One Life to Live)|Joe Riley]] (1969–70, 1974–79)|[[Steve Burke (One Life to Live)|Steve Burke]] (1972–74)|[[Clint Buchanan]] (1982–85, 1986–94, 2013–)|[[Sloan Carpenter]] (1994–95)|[[Ben Davidson (One Life to Live)|Ben Davidson]] (2000–04)|[[Charlie Banks (One Life to Live)|Charlie Banks]] (2009–11)}} | sons = {{ubl|[[Kevin Buchanan]]|[[Joey Buchanan]]}} | daughters = {{ubl|[[Megan Gordon]]|[[Jessica Buchanan]]|[[Natalie Buchanan]]}} | stepdaughters = [[Megan Craig Riley]] | grandsons = {{ubl|[[Duke Buchanan]]|[[Ryder Ford]]|[[Liam McBain]]}} | granddaughters = [[Bree Brennan]] | aunts/uncles = {{unbulleted list|Powell Lord|[[Gwendolyn Lord|Gwendolyn Lord Abbott]]|[[Dorothy Randolph]]}} | cousins = {{unbulleted list|[[Richard Abbott (One Life to Live)|Richard Abbott]]|Clayton-Powell Lord II}} | nieces/nephews = {{unbulleted list|[[Brian Kendall (One Life to Live)|Brian Kendall]]|[[Daniel Wolek]]|[[C. J. Roberts (One Life to Live)|C. J. Roberts]]|[[Sarah Roberts]]|[[Starr Manning]]|[[Danielle Manning]]|[[Jack Manning (One Life to Live)|Jack Manning]]|[[Sam Manning (One Life to Live)|Sam Manning]]|[[Victor Lord III]]}} | relatives = {{ubl|[[Zane Buchanan]]|[[Powell Lord III]]|[[Hope Manning-Thornhart]]}} }} '''Victoria Lord''' is a [[fictional character]] and [[matriarch]] of the [[Lord family]] on the American soap opera ''[[One Life to Live]]''. The character was created as one of the main [[protagonist]]s by series creator [[Agnes Nixon]], and first cast to [[Gillian Spencer]] on the [[television pilot|pilot]] aired July 15, 1968.{{cite book |last=Schemering |first=Christopher |authorlink=Christopher Schemering |title=[[The Soap Opera Encyclopedia (Schemering book)|The Soap Opera Encyclopedia]] |publisher=[[Ballantine Books]] |date = September 1985|pages=158–166|isbn=0345324595}} Nixon later recast her with [[Erika Slezak]], who became synonymous with the character role following a continual portrayal spanning her debut March 17, 1971 through the [[ABC Daytime]] finale January 13, 2012. Slezak reprised the role in [[The Online Network]] continuance of ''One Life to Live'' aired on [[Hulu]], [[iTunes]], [[FX Canada]], and the [[Oprah Winfrey Network (Canadian TV channel)|Oprah Winfrey Network]] from April 29, 2013{{cite news |title=''All My Children'', ''One Live to Live'' reborn via Hulu |author=Hal Boedeker |url=http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment_tv_tvblog/2013/01/all-my-children-one-live-to-live-reborn-via-hulu.html |newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |date=January 25, 2013 |accessdate=January 26, 2013}}{{cite news |title=''One Life To Live'', ''All My Children'' – New Episodes On The Way This Spring Via Hulu, iTunes |author=Jolie Lash |url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/one-life-to-live-all-my-children-new-episodes-on-the-way-this-spring-via-hulu-itunes_article_75634 |newspaper=[[Access Hollywood]] |date=January 25, 2013 |accessdate=January 26, 2013}} through the final episode released August 19, 2013.{{cite news|title=Reviving canceled ABC soap operas becomes a real-life drama|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/sep/03/business/la-fi-ct-epic-soap-20130828|first=Meg|last=James|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=September 3, 2013|accessdate=January 27, 2014}} The role of Victoria is the mainstay original lead character of the serial, and her storylines focus on drudgery, love, and family troubles. One of the longest-running characters on American [[daytime television]], Victoria weathers [[widow]]hood (three times), divorce (four times), a [[cerebral aneurysm|brain aneurysm]], a near-death [[out-of-body experience]] (three times), being shot (two times), sent to [[jail]], suffering a [[stroke]], [[breast cancer]], [[rape]], a [[heart attack]], [[heart disease]], a [[organ transplant|heart transplant]], the abduction of three of her five children as infants, the deaths of two siblings, and the death of her daughter from [[Systemic lupus erythematosus|lupus]]. Most notably, she suffers recurring bouts with [[dissociative identity disorder]] throughout the show [[plot (narrative)|narrative]]. Slezak's tenure as Victoria earned the actress a reputation as a [[leading actor]] in American [[serial (radio and television)|serial]]s,{{cite news |title=Slezak Wins Emmy; Lucci Shunned For A 16th Year Puppeteer Shari Lewis And Oprah Winfrey's Show Are Also Winners. |author=Tanya Barrientos |url=http://articles.philly.com/1996-05-23/news/25623566_1_erika-slezak-jess-walton-lucci-s-erica |newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date=May 23, 1996 |accessdate=May 26, 2013}}{{cite web |title=It’s Erika Slezak Day! ''OLTL'' honors her with 40th Anniversary Surprise Party! |last1=Michael |first1=Fairman |date=March 17, 2011 |url=http://michaelfairmansoaps.com/news/its-erika-slezak-day-oltl-honors-her-with-40th-anniversary-surprise-party/2011/03/17/ |accessdate=May 26, 2013}} {{cite journal |last1= Coulton |first1=Antoinette Y. |last2=Pham |first2=Thailan |year=2012 |title=Farewell to ''One Life to Live'' |journal=[[People (magazine)|People]] |volume=77 |issue=2 |pages= |publisher=[[Time Inc.]] |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20559463,00.html |accessdate=May 22, 2013}} {{cite journal |last1=Logan |first1=Michael |year=2012 |title=Erika Slezak Goes to Heaven One Last Time on ''One Life to Live'' |journal=[[TV Guide]] |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Erika-Slezak-OLTL-1041253.aspx |accessdate=May 22, 2013}}{{cite journal |last1=McConnell |first1=Michael |year=2011 |title=''The View'' Plans ''One Life to Live'' Special for Series Finale |journal=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/one-life-to-live-the-view-erika-slezak-270889 |accessdate=May 22, 2013}} with her portrayal becoming one of the [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series|most lauded]] and [[list of longest-serving soap opera actors#United States|longest-running]] in American [[soap opera]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.soapoperadigest.com/soapstarstats/erikaslezakbio |title=SOAP STAR STATS: Erika Slezak (Viki, ''OLTL'') |publisher=SoapOperaDigest.com ([[Internet Archive]]) |accessdate=March 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330095927/http://www.soapoperadigest.com/soapstarstats/erikaslezakbio |archivedate=March 30, 2010 }} ==Character background== {{quote box |width = 25em |border = 1px |bgcolor = #A4DDED |fontsize = 88% | quote = "It is a very, very good job, but it takes a lot of work, and it takes responsibility. You are responsible to the audience for who you’re playing. You’re responsible to your writers and your producer for the character, and you are extremely responsible to your fellow actors. There are people who don’t realize that." | source = —Erika Slezak on playing Victoria Lord, [[Archive of American Television]]{{cite web |url=http://emmytvlegends.org/interviews/people/erika-slezak |title=Erika Slezak, Actress |year=2006 |work=[[Archive of American Television]] |publisher=[[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] |accessdate=August 22, 2012}} | align = left }} ===Conception=== ''One Life to Live'' series creator Agnes Nixon conceived the central role of Victoria "Viki" Lord inspired by her relationship with her domineering father, Harry Eckhardt, and her own married family life along the [[Philadelphia Main Line]] in [[Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania|Bryn Mawr]].{{cite journal |author=Michael Callahan |year=2007 |title=Legends: The Original Desperate Housewife |journal=[[Philadelphia (magazine)|Philadelphia]] |issue=May 2007 |publisher=[[Metrocorp]] |url=http://www.phillymag.com/articles/legends-the-original-desperate-housewife/ |accessdate=August 21, 2012 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.shemadeit.org/meet/biography.aspx?m=45 |title=She Made It: Agnes Nixon, Television Writer, Producer |work=[[Paley Center for Media|The Paley Center for Media]] |accessdate=August 20, 2012}} Nixon took further inspiration from lead protagonist Tracy Lord of the 1939 play ''[[The Philadelphia Story (play)|The Philadelphia Story]]'',{{cite book |title=No End to Her: Soap Opera and the Female Subject |last=Nochimson |first=Martha |year=1993 |publisher=[[University of California Press]] |location=[[Berkeley, California]] |isbn=9780520077713 |page=64 |accessdate=July 11, 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3b-ufUPQ6qsC&lpg=PA64&pg=PA64#v=onepage&q&f=false}}{{cite web |url=http://www.showbiz411.com/2012/01/03/one-life-to-live-has-but-9-episodes-left-starting-today |title=''One Life to Live'' Has But 9 Episodes Left Starting Today |author=[[Roger Friedman]] |date=January 3, 2012 |work=[[Showbiz411]] |accessdate=July 13, 2012}} portrayed on stage and [[The Philadelphia Story (film)|film]] by actress [[Katharine Hepburn]]. ===Casting=== The role of Victoria was originally cast to Gillian Spencer, who appeared from the July 1968 debut until 1970. [[Joanne Dorian]] replaced Spencer from October 1970 until March 16, 1971, when established theater actress Erika Slezak stepped into the role in the following day's episode. Slezak became synonymous with the character role since her first appearance in the role March 17, 1971, playing Victoria [[list of longest-serving soap opera actors#United States|continually for 41 years]] until the original ''One Life'' television finale in 2012. Slezak reprised the role onscreen upon [[Prospect Park (production company)|Prospect Park]] resumption of the serial from April 29, 2013 through the final episode released August 19, 2013. Two other actresses portrayed Victoria while Slezak was on [[parental leave|maternity]] and personal leave: [[Christine Jones (actress)|Christine Jones]] in 1980 and 1981,[http://www.soapcentral.com/oltl/whoswho/victoria.php Victoria Lord Davidson profile – SoapCentral.com] and [[Judith Barcroft]] in 1987. In the summer of 2003, Slezak's real-life daughter, [[Amanda Davies (actress)|Amanda Davies]], portrayed a teenaged Victoria in flashbacks. Leah Marie Hays played the role of a young Victoria Lord in a series of flashbacks as well. At the death of show and character creator [[Agnes Nixon]] in 2016, Slezak [[eulogy|eulogized]] that, "When she hired me to play Viki on ''One Life To Live'', she changed my life and my career and I will forever be grateful to her."{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160929102426/http://www.erikaslezak.com/ |url=http://www.erikaslezak.com |title=Agnes Nixon: A Note from Erika about Agnes Nixon |author= |archivedate=September 29, 2016 |date=September 28, 2016 |website=Erika Slezak Fan Club |access-date=September 29, 2016 |quote="I am so terribly saddened by the death of Agnes Nixon. She was more than a great writer, producer and boss, she was a warm, loving and wonderful woman with a truly delightful and somewhat wicked sense of humor. It was my very great privilege to have known her and to have worked for her. When she hired me to play Viki on One Life To Live, she changed my life and my career and I will forever be grateful to her. I wish her peace and angels all around her. She deserves that!"}} Slezak expressed interest for reprising portrayal of the character in a short-term [[guest appearance]] on ABC's last remaining soap opera, ''[[General Hospital]]'', in a March 2018 interview with ''[[Soap Opera Digest]]'' magazine, ahead of the 50th anniversary of the July 1968 premiere of ''One Life to Live''.{{cite magazine |last=Larson |first=Kelli M. |date=March 21, 2018 |title=''ONE LIFE TO LIVE'' Star Erika Slezak Opens up About Her Return to Television (EXCLUSIVE) |url=http://www.abc.soapsindepth.com/posts/one-life-to-live-erika-slezak-the-resident-155754 |magazine=[[Soap Opera Digest]] |access-date=April 21, 2018}} ===Characterization=== At the debut episode of ''One Life to Live'' July 15, 1968, twentysomething recent college graduate and [[heir]]ess Victoria "Viki" Lord is described by author Martha Nochimson as "blonde [and] ivory-complexioned... the clichéd American princess," personifying the "woman on a pedestal" archetype. The show's [[hero]]ine from the outset, [[ingenue (stock character)|ingenue]] Victoria initially harbors a strong [[Electra complex]] and suffers a bout with [[dissociative identity disorder|multiple personalities]] prompted by her mother [[Eugenia Randolph|Eugenia]]'s absence from childhood and father [[Victor Lord|Victor]]'s incessant grooming of her to eventually helm the family's communication business, [[Lord Enterprises]]. As Erika Slezak stepped into the role in 1971, head writer Nixon matured Victoria to a self-assured working woman managing fictional [[Llanview]]'s predominant newspaper, ''The Banner''. An increasingly headstrong Victoria, relinquishing her primal desires to pander to Victor, marries working-class ''Banner'' editor [[Joe Riley (One Life to Live)|Joe Riley]], much to the patriarch's chagrin. By the mid-1980s, Victoria largely adopts a matronly role{{cite journal |year=1995 |journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |volume=145 |issue=18–26 |pages=76 |publisher=[[Time Inc.]]}} along with her capacities as well-connected town businesswoman and socialite, though she is still plagued with intermittent bouts of mental illness. The character comes to mother five of her own children onscreen (three from infancy), while providing surrogate nurture to younger siblings [[Tina Lord|Tina]] and [[Todd Manning|Todd]]. Since 2000s, the role has evolved to be regarded as the "[[grande dame]] of Llanview." In a 2006 ''[[Boston (magazine)|Boston]]'' magazine article, Slezak remarked of Victoria representing "the very classy, very old-world money," with writer Michael Callahan calling the character "the stiff-upper-lipped matriarch" of the prominent [[Lord family]]. American journalist and soap opera critic [[Connie Passalacqua Hayman]] ([[pen name]] "Marlena De Lacroix") briefly summed up the character role:
"... Slezak's 'Viki' is the consummate soap opera heroine, because she has so harrowingly and humanistically triumphed over all her life's tragedies."{{cite web |url=http://www.welovesoaps.net/2010/02/50-greatest-soap-actresses-3-erika.html |title=50 Greatest Soap Actresses: #3 Erika Slezak |author=Staff writer |date=February 7, 2010 |website=[[We Love Soaps]] |accessdate=May 31, 2013}}
==Character development== ===1960s and 1970s=== The eldest child of domineering millionaire publisher [[Victor Lord]] ([[Ernest Graves (actor)|Ernest Graves]]), Victoria Lord, often nicknamed "Viki," (originally Spencer) has little time for romance when ''One Life to Live'' begins in 1968.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |year=1968 |season=1 |language=English}} She clashes with reporter [[Joe Riley (One Life to Live)|Joe Riley]] ([[Lee Patterson]]), but they soon fall in love; Victor disapproves and tries to keep them apart. Torn between pleasing her father and following her heart, Viki develops a wild [[dissociative identity disorder|alternate personality]] named "Niki Smith", who falls in love with [[Vince Wolek|Vinny Wolek]] ([[Antony Ponzini]]). Viki's illness — apparently caused by seeing her pregnant mother fall down the stairs as a child — is eventually treated, and she and Joe marry December 11, 1969.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=December 11, 1969 |season=2 |language=English}}{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1968-69/1968.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1968–69) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=November 21, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423033131/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1968-69/1968.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}} Joe is presumed dead in a car accident in 1970, and a heartbroken Viki (Slezak onward) finds comfort with fellow reporter [[Steve Burke (One Life to Live)|Steve Burke]] (Bernie Grant) in 1971. After Steve is put on trial and exonerated for the murder of ''Banner'' secretary [[Marcy Wade]] ([[Francesca James]]), he and Viki marry in 1972.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=February 29, 1972 |season=4 |language=English}} When a very-much alive Joe returns in-time for the nuptials, having survived his supposedly deadly car accident, Viki is forced to choose between two husbands. Viki initially stays married to Steve out of obligation, but ultimately divorces him in January 1974. That summer, Dr. [[Dorian Lord|Dorian Cramer]] (then [[Nancy Pinkerton]]) blames board member Viki for her suspension from Llanview Hospital, and a rivalry is born that will last decades. Viki and Joe remarry in a simple, [[New York City]] ceremony in September.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=September 16, 1974 |season=7 |language=English}}{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1973-74/1973.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1973–74) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=May 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423033118/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1973-74/1973.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}} In 1975, Dorian becomes the private physician to Viki's father Victor, soon [[elopement (marriage)|eloping]] with him.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=May 9, 1975 |season=7 |language=English}} Viki learns she has a half-brother, [[Tony Lord (One Life to Live)|Tony Lord]] ([[George Reinholt]]), and Dorian plots to keep Victor's fortune for herself.{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1974-75/19742.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1974–75, Part 2) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=May 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423040812/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1974-75/19742.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}} In 1976, Victor suffers a heart attack and dies after wife Dorian denies him medication, and in his wake Dorian wreaks havoc on the Lord family. Viki and Joe have a son, [[Kevin Buchanan|Kevin Lord Riley]], who is soon kidnapped by jealous [[Cathy Craig|Cathy Craig Lord]] (then Jennifer Harmon), but is later returned.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=1976–77 |season=9 |language=English}} In 1978, Viki takes in [[Tina Lord|Tina Clayton]] ([[Andrea Evans]]), the sixteen-year-old daughter of college roommate and best friend [[Irene Manning (One Life to Live)|Irene Manning Clayton]] (Kate McKeown), who is apparently dying of cancer.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=July 1978 |season=10 |language=English}} Shortly after Irene dies, Viki goes on trial for the murder of her nemesis [[Marco Dane]] ([[Gerald Anthony]]), but she is later exonerated following confessional testimony by [[Karen Wolek]] ([[Judith Light]]).{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=1978–79 |season=11 |language=English}} Joe dies from a [[brain tumor]] in October 1979,{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=October 3, 1979 |season=12 |language=English}} and Viki gives birth to their second son, [[Joey Buchanan|Joe Riley, Jr.]], in January 1980.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=January 8, 1980 |season=12 |language=English}}{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1979-80/1979.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1979–80) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=May 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423033208/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1979-80/1979.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}} ===1980s=== After a disastrous relationship with con man [[Ted Clayton (One Life to Live)|Ted Clayton]],{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1980-81/19801.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1980–81, Part 2) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=May 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423040956/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1980-81/19801.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}}{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1981-82/19811.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1981–82, Part 2) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=May 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423040718/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1981-82/19811.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}} who brainwashes and drugs her in an attempt to get his hands on her fortune, Viki marries newspaper editor [[Clint Buchanan]] ([[Clint Ritchie]]) in 1982; he adopts both of her sons.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=November 15, 1982 |season=15 |language=English}} [[Echo DiSavoy]] ([[Kim Zimmer]]), seeking revenge on Clint for her mother's murder, seduces him in 1983 to ruin his marriage, then fakes her own death and frames him for it. Clint is later exonerated after Echo is found alive, and he and Viki reunite.{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1983-84/19832.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1983–84, Part 3) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=May 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423053158/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1983-84/19832.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}} Viki is shocked to discover in 1985 that her former ward Tina Clayton (Evans) is in fact her half-sister, daughter of Viki's father Victor and not Ted. Thanks to the machinations of Tina's boyfriend [[Mitch Laurence]] ([[Roscoe Born]]), Viki succumbs to the pressure and Niki Smith returns. Posing as Viki, Niki divorces Clint; Viki later overcomes her illness with the realization that it had actually been triggered by her witnessing Victor and Irene in bed many years before.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=1985–86 |season=18 |language=English}} Clint and Viki remarry in 1986,{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=April 17, 1986 |season=18 |language=English}} and Viki gives birth to their daughter [[Jessica Buchanan]] in September 1986. Jessica is kidnapped shortly after birth by [[Allison Perkins]] ([[Barbara Garrick]]), a disciple of Mitch Laurence; Jessica is soon returned unharmed in December, and Allison institutionalized. In 1988, Viki learns that she married and gave birth to a child in high school with high school sweetheart [[Roger Gordon (One Life to Live)|Roger Gordon]] ([[Larry Pine]]), but father Victor had her hypnotized to forget the occurrences. With Viki's memory restored in 1989, she annuls her 1960s off-screen marriage to Roger and initiates a relationship with daughter [[Megan Gordon]] ([[Jessica Tuck]]), an actress on the [[story within a story|soap opera (within a soap opera)]], ''Fraternity Row''. Megan and Viki initially spar, but ultimately get past their initial conflicts and become close.{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1983-84/19832.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1989–90) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=May 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423033243/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1989-90/1989.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}} ===1990s=== In 1990, Viki is elected mayor of Llanview,{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=May 1990 |season=22 |language=English}} but a shooting and subsequent [[stroke]] leaves her paralyzed and in a wheelchair;{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=August–September 1990 |season=23 |language=English}} Niki Smith emerges to aid a paralyzed Viki stand up and shoot [[Johnny Dee Hesser]] ([[Anthony Crivello]]) when he attacks Tina.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=November 8, 1990 |season=23 |language=English}} Viki recovers and later donates a kidney to daughter Megan suffering terminal [[Systemic lupus erythematosus|lupus]], but Megan dies, leaving Viki devastated.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=August 1991 |season=23 |language=English}}{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=February 7, 1992 |season=23 |language=English}} Growing ever-distant from Clint, Viki engages an extramarital affair with [[Sloan Carpenter]] ([[Roy Thinnes]]); she and Clint divorce in 1994, and she marries Sloan. Sloan dies soon after from [[Hodgkin's lymphoma]], just as the existence of a second child of Victor and Irene's is revealed.{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1994-95/1994.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1994–95) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=June 26, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423033216/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1994-95/1994.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}} Viki's stress reaches a critical point when Dorian ([[Robin Strasser]] onward) tells Viki a secret of which she thought Viki had been aware: the fact that Victor had sexually abused his daughter as a child. With this trauma being what had actually initiated Viki's [[dissociative identity disorder]], she subsequently splinters into several personalities, one of which imprisons Dorian in a secret room below Llanfair. Dorian is eventually freed from her confinement, and Viki recovers after realizing she herself (more specifically, one of her alternate personalities) was the one who had smothered Victor to death in 1976.In recent years, ''One Life to Live'' plot twists have strongly suggested that Dorian was Victor's true murderer after all, as was suggested at Victor's initial death in 1976. In August 2007, Dorian makes the startling (and vague) claim to Viki that she had actually killed Victor, and that a man who appeared in 2003 claiming to be Victor was a fraud. Having planted [[Lord family#A seed of doubt|a seed of doubt]] in Viki's mind, she refused to elaborate. On August 16, 2011, Dorian's husband [[David Vickers|David Vickers Buchanan]] ([[Tuc Watkins]]) mentions that an (albeit forged) entry from Irene Manning's diary cleared Dorian of Victor's murder. When David states that Dorian is innocent of the crime, she comments to herself, "... or so Viki chooses to believe." In 1995, reviled town outcast [[Todd Manning]] ([[Roger Howarth]]) is proven to be Victor and Irene's illegitimate son; Viki and Todd eventually become close.{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1995-96/1995.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (1995–96) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=June 26, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423033103/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/1995-96/1995.html |archivedate=April 23, 2008}} After a failed reconciliation attempt with Clint, Viki meets and falls in love with [[Ben Davidson (One Life to Live)|Ben Davidson]] ([[Mark Derwin]]),{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=1999 |season=30 |language=English}} who is eventually revealed to be the long-lost son of [[Asa Buchanan]] ([[Philip Carey]]) and [[Renée Divine Buchanan]] ([[Patricia Elliott]]). Ben's first wife, [[Skye Chandler]] ([[Robin Christopher]]), comes to town and tries in vain to keep Ben and Viki apart.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=1999–2000 |season=31 |language=English}} ===2000s=== Viki is diagnosed with [[breast cancer]] in 2000, but survives after a mastectomy and chemotherapy.{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=February–August 2000 |season=31–32 |language=English}} She and Ben marry in November.{{cite web |url=http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/2000-01/1100.html |title=''One Life to Live'' recap (November 2000) |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |accessdate=June 26, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080402062227/http://abc.go.com/daytime/onelifetolive/episodes/2000-01/1100.html |archivedate=April 2, 2008}} In 2001, a girl named [[Natalie Buchanan|Natalie Balsom]] ([[Melissa Archer]]) makes the startling claim that she is Viki and Clint's biological daughter, which is confirmed by a [[genetic fingerprinting|DNA test]].{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=October 2001 |season=33 |language=English}} Mitch Laurence returns from the dead, divulging to Viki he drugged and raped her around the same time she and Clint conceived Jessica and had unknowingly become pregnant with fraternal twins, one fathered by Clint, Natalie, and the other fathered by Mitch, Jessica ([[Erin Torpey]]).{{Cite episode |series=One Life to Live |serieslink=One Life to Live |network=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=November–December 2002 |season=34 |language=English}} Unable to reconcile the revelation, Niki Smith emerges during the ordeal and plots to kill Ben in order to have her freedom, but when Ben is accidentally shot by [[Antonio Vega (character)|Antonio Vega]] ([[Kamar de los Reyes]]), Viki returns. Ben is left comatose after the shooting. In 2003, Victor (William Stone Mahoney) is ostensibly revealed to be alive, claiming to have faked his death in 1976; however, shortly after he returns, Victor dies — but not before Viki and Todd confront him on ills inflicted to them in his wake. In 2004, Viki is diagnosed with heart disease and eventually needs a heart transplant. Coincidentally, a comatose Ben dies just as Viki takes a turn for the worse, and his heart is transplanted into Viki, who recovers but must face widowhood once again.{{cite news |title=All My Stories |author=Renee Michael |url=http://6thfloor.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/04/19/all-my-stories/ |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 19, 2011 |accessdate=June 29, 2013}} In 2007, Viki and Clint ([[Jerry verDorn]]) start dating again, but Dorian decides she wants Clint for herself and plots to break up the couple. Dorian's schemes succeed, and Clint ends things with Viki to start a new relationship with Dorian. Feeling humiliated and defeated, Viki leaves Llanview for a much-needed vacation and finds herself in [[Paris, Texas]], where she tries to reinvent herself by waiting tables at a local diner. It is there that she meets patron [[Charlie Banks (One Life to Live)|Charlie Banks]] ([[Brian Kerwin]]), a recovering alcoholic, and the two begin seeing one another. Viki ultimately returns to Llanview once her family discovers her secret life, and Charlie's search for his estranged son [[Jared Banks|Jared]] ([[John Brotherton]]) leads him there as well. Viki and Charlie resume their relationship, but break up when Viki discovers that Charlie had lied about the identity of his son in extenuating circumstances. In July 2008, Viki is involved in a car accident with Dorian; Viki's heart stops as a result of the crash, but Dorian manages to revive her. Reexamining her life, Viki reunites with Charlie, and they marry on August 4, 2009. Viki runs for mayor against Dorian and wins; she steps down, however, to help her family deal with the unexpected return of Mitch Laurence, who wreaks havoc on her daughters and murders Jared in the process. ===2010–12=== Charlie, devastated over his son's death, quits his sobriety and began drinking, distancing himself from Viki, choosing instead to conspire with Dorian to kill Mitch. Though Dorian tries to stop him at the last minute, Charlie ends up accidentally shooting Jessica ([[Bree Williamson]] onward), who survives. Devastated by Charlie's actions, Viki asks him for a divorce, but they eventually reconcile. Viki and Charlie's marriage is further complicated by the return of Echo DiSavoy, a woman who almost destroyed her marriage to Clint in 1983. Echo begins insinuating herself into Charlie and Viki's marriage, much to Viki's dismay. When a paternity revealed Charlie not to be the father of [[Rex Balsom]] ([[John-Paul Lavoisier]]), a devastated Charlie turns to Echo for comfort. Dorian, who had suspicions about Echo and Charlie's dealings, forged a truce with Viki to uncover Charlie's misgivings. A devastated Viki finds out about Charlie's affair and definitively asks him for a divorce. After confronting Charlie and Echo, Viki goes to court to fight for custody of grandson [[Ryder Ford]] while his mother Jessica was ill with her multiple personality. A stressed Viki suffers a bout with multiple personalities on the stand, leading the judge against giving the child to Viki but instead to her son and daughter-in-law, Joey (Tom Degnan) and [[Aubrey Wentworth|Aubrey Buchanan]] ([[Terri Conn]]). In summer 2011 a man with the "original" face of her only known living brother, Todd (Howarth), returned to Llanview claiming to be the victim of eight years of imprisonment and torture at the hands of his mother and Viki's childhood friend, a back-from-the-dead Irene Manning ([[Barbara Rhoades]]). After medical tests revealed the "newer" Todd ([[Trevor St. John]]) and the "old" Todd (Howarth) to have identical DNA, Irene appeared to reveal the "two Todds" to be twins. The man who resembled Walker Laurence (St. John) and who has been living as Todd since 2003 was revealed actually have been born [[Victor Lord, Jr.]], brainwashed into believing that he is Todd by Irene. Meanwhile, Viki agrees in court to put up Clint in Llanfair for [[house arrest]] after he was convicted of various crimes in Llanview. Dorian and Viki ostensibly put an end to their feud of nearly four decades when Dorian leaves town to become an acting [[United States Senate|U.S. senator]]. Viki continues work at ''The Banner'' when Tina returns to town for the reading of the will of recently murdered Victor, Jr. After months of rehashing old feelings and living under the same roof, Clint and Viki too admit to their unresolved feelings and agreed to give a romantic relationship one more try. At the original finale, a prison breakout leads Allison Perkins to shoot both Clint and Viki, but only after telling the two that Jessica was in fact Clint's daughter and not the daughter of Mitch Laurence. Clint sanctioned another paternity test and, in the presence of Jessica, Viki, and Natalie, revealed Allison's claim to be true. Following all the emotional revelations and tears, Clint again declares his undying love for Viki and asks her to marry him for a third time. ===2013=== Upon the series resumption in April 2013, Viki accepts Clint's marriage proposal, and concurrently hires freelance journalist [[Jeffrey King]] ([[Corbin Bleu]]) to investigate the alleged congressional malfeasance of junior U.S. senator Dorian. Upon visiting niece [[Danielle Manning]] (Kelley Missal) in the hospital after overdosing on drugs and alcohol, she uncovers her brother Victor, Jr. to be alive. With her family newspaper in financial straits, ''The Banner'' focuses on growing the publication's online presence. ===Alternate personalities=== [[File:Nikismith1985.png|thumb|right|Slezak as Victoria's main alter-ego Niki Smith in 1985, a performance for which she earned the [[13th Daytime Emmy Awards|1986 Daytime Emmy Award]] for [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series|Lead Actress in a Drama Series]]]] As of the final ABC episode, all of Victoria's six{{cite book |title=The ''One Life to Live'' 40th Anniversary Trivia Book |last=Waggett |first=Gerry |year=2008 |publisher=[[Hyperion Books]] |location=[[New York City]] |isbn=9781401323097 |accessdate=August 19, 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FxIAmjBPZCQC&lpg=PA186&ots=jPIY92jufN}} alternate personalities are integrated with her baseline psyche. At times during the series, Viki has been forced to impersonate one of them, particularly Niki and Jean. In order of their first appearance on ''One Life to Live'', they are: * '''Nicole "Niki" Smith''' – a devil-may-care, sexually promiscuous party girl, approximately 22 years old. First appearing on the episode first-run November 15, 1968, Niki appears more times than all of the other alters combined, and is very skilled at masquerading as Viki when necessary to hide her re-emergence.{{Cite episode |title= |series= One Life to Live |series-link= One Life to Live |network= [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=November 15, 1968 |season= 1 |credits = Doris Quinlan ([[Executive producer]]); [[Agnes Nixon]], Paul Roberts and Don Wallace ([[Head writer]]s)}} Niki has had two serious relationships with [[Vince Wolek]] (1968–69) and [[Harry O'Neill (One Life to Live)|Harry O'Neill]] (1985); neither Vinny or Harry realized at the time that Niki was an alter of Viki. * '''Tommy''' – a 14-year-old male alter emerged in 1995, who embodied Viki's anger and rage at her abuse.{{Cite episode |title= |series= One Life to Live |series-link= One Life to Live |network= [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |date=February 2, 1995 |season= 27 |credits = Susan Bedsow Horgan ([[Executive producer]]); [[Michael Malone]] and [[Josh Griffith]] ([[Head writer]]s)}} Tommy usually emerged to protect Princess (another alternate personality), and once threw [[Dorian Lord]] down the La Boulaie staircase and attempted to beat her to death with a [[claw hammer]] in the Llanfair secret room. * '''Jean Randolph''' – Jean Randolph is the calm, cool, collected and calculating caretaker of all the other alters, who took over when Viki's abusive childhood was revealed. Her name is derived from that of Viki's mother, Eugenia Randolph Lord. Jean blackmailed con man [[David Vickers]] into divorcing Viki's sister, [[Tina Lord|Tina]], and also freed Viki's son, [[Joey Buchanan|Joey]], from Dorian Lord's clutches by imprisoning Dorian in a secret room in the basement of Llanfair, which led Joey to believe that Dorian left him. Jean then forced Dorian to marry David to keep them both occupied and away from Viki's loved ones. * '''Princess''' – a manifestation of Viki as a seven-year-old girl. She is a traumatized child who is constantly reliving the molestation by Viki's father. Protected by Tommy, the 14-year-old alternate personality, who is most angry about the abuse. * '''Tori Lord''' – Tori emerged in 1995, approximately 19 years old, after Dorian revealed the truth of Victor's abuse to Viki. It was established that Tori was the alter who murdered Victor Lord in 1976. (It would later be revealed that Victor survived and did not die until 2003. However Dorian has planted [[Lord family#A seed of doubt|a seed of doubt]] regarding that notion, suggesting that the man who re-emerged as Victor in 2003 was a fraud.) Although her declared mission was to force Viki to face the truth, she wreaked much destruction before getting around to that. Tori started undermining ''The Banner'' by feeding stories and information to rival newspaper editor [[Todd Manning]], and she torched Llanfair, nearly killing Jessica in the blaze. * '''Victor Lord''' – this personality is the reflective image of Viki's abusive father, Victor. The Victor Lord personality only emerged two or three times, but one of the instances that he took over led Viki to attempt suicide by cutting her own wrists to "expel" Victor from her body. ==Reception== Series [[fansite]] ''Llanview Labyrinth'' remarks that although Gillian Spencer's Victoria is featured at the show's outset, "the obviousness of Viki being the show[']s unquestioned 'lead' did not smack the viewer quite as hard as it later would [with Erika Slezak's portrayal],"{{cite web |url=http://llanviewlabyrinth.webs.com/recastcontrasts/recasts_viki.html |title=Victoria "Viki" Lord |author=Staff writer |year=2012 |website=Llanview Labyrinth |accessdate=May 26, 2013}} with Spencer's Victoria melding into the [[ensemble cast]]. Joanne Dorian briefly stepped into the role beginning in October 1970, with a markedly less dynamic presence on the series than her predecessor. In March 1971, ''One Life to Live'' executive producer Doris Quinlan remarked to ''After Noon TV'' magazine of Erika Slezak and her audition before herself, series creator and head writer Agnes Nixon, and director David Pressman, "You've got to meet this girl—she's going to be a star."{{cite journal |year=1971 |title=Three Wishes for Erika |journal=After Noon TV |url=http://www.geocities.com/Hollywood/Academy/6053/ar71_.html |accessdate=August 19, 2012 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091026231445/http://www.geocities.com/Hollywood/Academy/6053/ar71_.html | archivedate=October 26, 2009}} Since the introduction of Slezak as Victoria, her portrayal has become regarded as definitive to the role. Slezak's work has garnered her the acclaim of media critics and viewers alike, earning the actress comparisons between herself and contemporary film star [[Meryl Streep]] for perceived similarities in acting range, versatility, and numerous award nominations.{{cite news |title="All My Children": Goodbye to a fondly remembered world |author=Hal Bodoedeker |url=http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment_tv_tvblog/tag/erika-slezak |newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |date=April 17, 2011 |accessdate=July 13, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.soapcentral.com/oltl/news/2008/1103-slezak_iview_01.php |title=One-on-One with One Life to Live's Erika Slezak |author=Dan J. Kroll |date=October 29, 2008 |work=[[SoapCentral]] |accessdate=July 13, 2012}} Slezak has received nine [[Daytime Emmy Award]] nominations in the category of [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series|Outstanding Lead Actress]] for her portrayal of Victoria, winning in 1984,{{cite web|url=http://www.soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1984/index.html|title=Daytime Emmy Winners & Nominees: 1984|publisher=SoapOperaDigest.com|accessdate=February 20, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402151614/http://www.soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1984/index.html|archivedate=April 2, 2009|df=mdy-all}} 1986,{{cite web|url=http://www.soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1986/index.html|title=Daytime Emmy Winners & Nominees: 1986|publisher=SoapOperaDigest.com|accessdate=February 20, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060527180514/http://soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1986/index.html|archivedate=May 27, 2006|df=mdy-all}} 1992,{{cite web|url=http://www.soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1992/index.html|title=Daytime Emmy Winners & Nominees: 1992|publisher=SoapOperaDigest.com|accessdate=February 20, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060527183727/http://soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1992/index.html|archivedate=May 27, 2006|df=mdy-all}} 1995,{{cite web|url=http://www.soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1995/index.html|title=Daytime Emmy Winners & Nominees: 1995|publisher=SoapOperaDigest.com|accessdate=February 20, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060527182335/http://soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1995/index.html|archivedate=May 27, 2006|df=mdy-all}} 1996,{{cite web|url=http://www.soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1996/index.html|title=Daytime Emmy Winners & Nominees: 1996|publisher=SoapOperaDigest.com|accessdate=February 20, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603195636/http://www.soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners1996/index.html|archivedate=June 3, 2009|df=mdy-all}} and 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners2005/index.html|title=Daytime Emmy Winners & Nominees: 2005|publisher=SoapOperaDigest.com|accessdate=February 20, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402151629/http://www.soapoperadigest.com/Emmys/winners2005/index.html|archivedate=April 2, 2009|df=mdy-all}} At the finale of the show's last iteration, she held the record for most Emmy wins by an actress. She also garnered the [[Soap Opera Digest|''Soap Opera Digest'' Award]] for Favorite Couple with co-star [[Mark Derwin]] ([[Ben Davidson (One Life to Live)|Ben Davidson]]) in 2000. In 2002, in recognition for her work on ''One Life to Live'', Slezak was inducted as a member of the Silver Circle of the [[New York City|New York]] chapter of the [[National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences]] for over a quarter-century of "significant contributions" to television.{{cite web |url=http://www.nyemmys.org/en/cms/?53 |title=Silver Circle |year=2012 |publisher=[[National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences|National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences: New York]] |accessdate=August 29, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.erikaslezak.com/emmys.htm |title=Erika Slezak Awards and Emmys |year=2012 |work=ErikaSlezak.com |accessdate=August 29, 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://a.abc.com/daytime/onelifetolive/bios/viki_davidson.html web|url=http://soapoperadigest.com/features/one-life-to-live/pandt/personalities/index.html|title=''One Life to Live'' Timeline: Cult of Personalities|publisher=SoapOperaDigest.com|accessdate=February 19, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402151639/http://soapoperadigest.com/features/one-life-to-live/pandt/personalities/index.html|archivedate=April 2, 2009|df=mdy-all}} '''Woldemichael Solomon''' was an [[Eritrea]]n ruler. He served as the [[Ras (title)|Ras]] (Prince) of the [[Medri Bahri]] kingdom and [[Hamasien]] during the 19th century. [[File:Ras_Woldemichael_Solomon,_Ruler_of_MedriBahri.jpg|thumb|right|''Ras'' of [[Medri Bahri]].]]
==Life== Ras Woldemichael was born into the Hazega clan.<ref name="Caulk">{{cite journal |last1=Caulk |first1=Richard |title=Bad Men of the Borders: Shum and Shefta in Northern Ethiopia in the 19th Century |journal=The International Journal of African Historical Studies |date=1984 |volume=17 |issue=2 |pages=201–227 |doi=10.2307/218604 |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/218604 |accessdate=2 September 2018}}</ref>
He served as prince of [[Hazega]] in [[Eritrea]]. His unofficial title was Ras, Woldemichael Solomon because, although he ruled as a king, his leadership ended before he was crowned the Governor of Hamasien (which is mainly located in present-day Eritrea, where he is widely celebrated as a hero standing for Eritrean sovereignty).<ref name="DenisonPaice2007">{{cite book|author1=Edward Denison|author2=Edward Paice|title=Eritrea: The Bradt Travel Guide|url={{google books|plainurl=y|id=Qi-KQchGks8C}}|year=2007|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=978-1-84162-171-5}}</ref>
Ras Woldemichael Solomon fought against Emperor [[Yohannes IV]] who sent Ras [[Alula Engida|Alula]] to fight him. When Ras Alula became aware of the difficulties fighting Woldemichael, he tricked him by arranging a peace treaty that he had no intention of observing, swearing on [[Bible|The Bible]] that he wouldn't attack. However, Alula broke his promise and imprisoned Ras Woldemichael at Amba Selama, ruling Hamasien himself afterwards. Woldemichael later settled in [[Axum]], [[Ethiopia]] until his death in 1906.
